urn:contentItem:5W2T-RYV1-DY0W-41TC-00000-00Facebook CEO, Mark Zuckerberg Did Not Show at a Major International Hearing in Great Britain; Google Also Under Fire by Seven Countries in Europe Who Say that Google is Still Secretly Tracking Users; Amazon Plans to Sell Software to Doctors and Hospitals to Mine Patients' Medical Records in an Attempt for Better Patient Service; Members of the Migrant Caravan Who Were Trying to Cross to the U.S. just Wrapped Up a Meeting and Have Listed Down Things They Want Going Forward to Their Plan; President Trump Threatens G.M. to Cut All Federal Subsidies Including the Company's Electric Cars after G.M. Announced It's Going to Lay Off about 14,800 of Its Workers and Close Down Plants in North America; Polio-Like Disease that Causes Paralysis is Now Spreading to 31 States, Sickening at Least 116 Children; Trump Threatens to Cancel Putin Meeting over Clash with Ukraine; Russia Detains Ukrainian Sailors after a Clash at Sea; Trump Pushes for $5 billion in Border Wall Funding; Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton Discusses How the U.S. Border Patrol Used Tear Gas on Migrants Attempting to Rush the U.S.-Mexico Border and President Trump's Push for Border Wall Funding; Fox News Contributor Jason Chaffetz on House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi's Push to Become House Speaker and How the U.S. Border Patrol Used Tear Gas on Migrants Attempting to Rush the Southern Border2018-11-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:45:28ZLexisNexisFacebook CEO, Mark Zuckerberg Did Not Show at a Major International Hearing in Great Britain; Google Also Under Fire by Seven Countries in Europe Who Say that Google is Still Secretly Tracking Users; Amazon Plans to Sell Software to Doctors and Hospitals to Mine Patients' Medical Records in an Attempt for Better Patient Service; Members of the Migrant Caravan Who Were Trying to Cross to the U.S. just Wrapped Up a Meeting and Have Listed Down Things They Want Going Forward to Their Plan; President Trump Threatens G.M. to Cut All Federal Subsidies Including the Company's Electric Cars after G.M. Announced It's Going to Lay Off about 14,800 of Its Workers and Close Down Plants in North America; Polio-Like Disease that Causes Paralysis is Now Spreading to 31 States, Sickening at Least 116 Children; Trump Threatens to Cancel Putin Meeting over Clash with Ukraine; Russia Detains Ukrainian Sailors after a Clash at Sea; Trump Pushes for $5 billion in Border Wall Funding; Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton Discusses How the U.S. Border Patrol Used Tear Gas on Migrants Attempting to Rush the U.S.-Mexico Border and President Trump's Push for Border Wall Funding; Fox News Contributor Jason Chaffetz on House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi's Push to Become House Speaker and How the U.S. Border Patrol Used Tear Gas on Migrants Attempting to Rush the Southern BorderLanhamFULL TEXT

(JOINED IN PROGRESS)

DAVID ASMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Thanks for joining us. "EVENING EDIT" starts right now.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We know from a recent investigation by "The New York Times" that Facebook was aware as a company much, much earlier that these ads were being placed and run.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Any information you can see contained within that cache of e-mails was, at best, partial. And at worst, potentially misleading.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This information can use public domain about keep the company's knowledge because of a separate investigation, not in the multiple hearings that the company has attended where they've been asked these questions.

They didn't report it to anyone at the time, and during the period when we were asking questions about it, no one disclosed that the company was aware of this information earlier.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I do want to set that context, and those e-mailed are unverified, partial accounts from a source who has a particular angle.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Wow, that was a heated exchange at a hearing in the U.K. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg a no-show at that major international hearing in Great Britain to answer new bombshell charges. It goes from bad to worse at Facebook.

We dig in to the stunning new allegations out of the U.K. based on Facebook e-mails the U.K. had seized. That Facebook was warned about Russians trolling through Facebook, harvesting your information much earlier than realized starting way back in 2014. Up to three billion data points a day.

This as U.S. senators here in this country warn Facebook may have broken the law. We explain.

Also coming up, Google now under fire by seven countries in Europe who now say Google is still secretly tracking you even after you turn it off. And that Google tricks you into giving it much more information about yourself and your families, more than you realize all without your consent.

This as Google workers now demand Google must stop building a censored search engine for China that that China can use to attract and arrest citizens that commit human rights violations. Protests worldwide on that, we're on it.

Also coming up to Capitol Hill, high-level meetings over the border wall funding. Will President Trump get what he wants, and wat is that poison pill that will cause Republican conservatives to defeat it?

Plus, details tonight on the new Republican push for results from that Justice Department probe into the Clinton Foundation. New details showing donations plummeting after Hillary lost the election. Republicans say that's proof that the Clintons engaged in pay to play.

Well, thank you so much for joining us, thank you for watching. Money, politics, we've got the debate behind tomorrow's headlines. I'm Elizabeth MacDonald. THE EVENING EDIT starts right now.

Welcome to the show. You're watching the Fox Business Network.

Over 100 Google workers publishing an open letter today, slamming Google, demanding it stop building a censored search engine for China. It's designed to possibly blacklist words like human rights or student protests. Fear is that China will use that Google search engine to arrest its own citizens and commit even more human rights violations.

Hillary Vaughn has the details. Hillary?

HILLARY VAUGHN, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Hi, Liz. Well, these Google engineers really are teaming up to take on Google, trying to get them to shut down the development of this dragonfly search engine. The Googlers pending a public letter. The list of signatories has been growing throughout the day.

The letter calling out Google for putting what they call profits over their own company's values that are supposed to include basic human rights.

The letter writing, quote, "Dragonfly in China would establish a dangerous precedent at a volatile political moment, one that would make it harder for Google to deny other countries similar concessions, providing the Chinese government with ready access to user data as required by Chinese law would make Google complicit in oppression and human rights abuses."

This is not the first time Googlers have sounded off about this product. The letter says thousands internally at Google have protested the tools. Many of these people that signed on to this letter are engineers, and they say they should have a say how the tools that they are building are being used and by who is using them.

Dragonfly would ramp up surveillance of Chinese citizens, sparking concerns that the government would use Google's data to silence dissenters, censor unpopular points of view, these are concerns that -- or there are concerns that the data would also make Chinese citizens less safe.

So, Google's been dealing with a lot of backlash about this not internally but also publicly too. Lawmakers on Capitol Hill, even vice President Mike pence calling for Google to stop the development of this product.

But each time Google has offered this same very statement that they wrote months ago, even though the letter today was published this morning, saying that their work on search in China is just exploratory, and they're not ready to launch anything soon, so we'll have to wait and see if Google decides to address publicly some of these concerns by their own employees.

But they're not the only tech company in the spotlight here. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg got shamed on Twitter after he failed to show up before lawmakers in the U.K. that were demanding answers over Russian activity on their platform after reports revealed that they could have been mining three billion bits of data from the site a day.

So, he didn't show up. Instead, he sent someone else. So, Britain's department of Digital, Culture, Media and Sport tweeted a photo of an empty chair with a name placard for Zuckerberg writing, "where is Mark Zuckerberg?"

Facebook sent their V.P. of policy solutions Richard Allan to answer questions from lawmakers that then grilled him over this and also the disappear -- or the absence of Facebook's CEO.

Zuckerberg has faced scrutiny in the U.K. for not facing lawmakers there after he faced Congress here in the U.S. They, of course, have a lot of questions that are very similar to a lot of the questions that lawmakers here on Capitol Hill had as well. Liz?

MACDONALD: Hillary Vaughn, great reporting. Thank you so much. And more trouble for Google.

VAUGHN: Thank you.

MACDONALD: Consumer groups and seven countries accusing Google of secretly tracking users' locations even after they turn off Google's locations settings, also letting Google is secretly building detailed profiles of users without our consent.

And to the new Facebook bombshell we are just talking about. Zuckerberg and those Facebook e-mails seized by the U.K. parliament that Facebook was warned that Russians were trolling through our data, harvesting way back starting in 2014, earlier than realized.

Again, you heard it, three billion data points a day, that's what the U.K. is saying.

Let's bring in Republican Florida Congressman Francis Rooney. Great to see you, sir.

REP. FRANCIS ROONEY, (R) FLORIDA: Thanks for having me on.

MACDONALD: What's your reaction to all of this?

ROONEY: Well, I think Facebook and Google are showing some of the abusive behavior that a dominant competitor can do, and I think we need to take seriously how we're going to deal with it.

I mean, this business of Google doing the things you just talked about, Facebook censoring conservative posts and sources, we can't allow them in a free society with a First Amendment to operate that way.

MACDONALD: Is there a growing consensus that Congress will try to regulate Facebook and social media? Because here we've got the U.S. Senator Amy Klobuchar saying Facebook may have broken a law by hiring a P.R. from to smear critics. She's worried that Facebook may be illegally using its mountain of data against government officials scrutinizing it including on the intelligence committees. Is there a push in Congress now to regulate these guys?

ROONEY: Well, we'll see what the incoming Democrat majority in the House wants to do. I've been pushing for two years that we follow the Europeans' attitude of bringing antitrust actions against Facebook and Google for their abusive market share and that we hold them accountable for data breaches.

MACDONALD: Are you going to hold hearings on it?

ROONEY: I hope they do. I mean, I think the things you just talked about, about Google keeping that information and discreetly and clandestinely keeping it and then with Facebook admitting that they've censored conservative sources in violation of the First Amendment are serious problems for me.

MACDONALD: You know, and, sir, also, U.K. politicians saying Facebook purposefully and knowingly set up a back door for companies like Cambridge Analytica to get in and take our information, also reading - reading our Facebook messages. We don't know who else is reading our Facebook messages, in effect saying, basically Facebook created, knowingly created a loophole and sold it. What do you think of that?

ROONEY: I think it's a total derogation of First Amendment and privacy rights, and we need to dig into it and address it. Just like this behavior in China. You know, Facebook wants to be protected by the power of the United States when they're threatened, but they're going to go in there and conspire with China?

MACDONALD: Yes, that's Google.

ROONEY: Google, yes. I mean.

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: That's Google.

ROONEY: We're -- you know, Lenin used to say the capitalists will sell us the ropes we'll use to hang them with. It sounds like Google is doing that.

MACDONALD: All right. Congressman Rooney, you're terrific. Will you come back on the show? We're going to stay on the story. We are going to need congressman like you on it. Can you come back on in the future?

ROONEY: I love to do it anytime. Thank you very much.

MACDONALD: Good to see you, sir. Good to see you.

Now we've got to keep an eye on Amazon, too. The Wall Street Journal reporting Amazon is stepping into our health data. Amazon is planning to sell software to doctors and hospitals to mine our medical records all in an attempt for better patient service. But you know what happens there, we're always worried about that.

Joining me now, Republican strategist Ford O'Connell and Democrat strategist, Kevin Walling. Ford, you heard -- Ford and Kevin. First to you, Ford. You heard our conversation just now on all of this. What's your reaction to all of this, Ford?

FORD O'CONNELL, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST: Well, look, I think that big tech is like the Wild West. There are no rules and, essentially, collectively they wield more power than big brother. And with Democrats taking back the House and with folks like Elizabeth Warren running for president, there are going to be regulations, the only question is when. Even Apple's Tim Cook admits as much.

MACDONALD: All right. Kevin, here's the thing, these guys act very altruistic in public. They act like, you know, we're sorry, we're altruistic, but then we're going to get your permission, we're going to get your consent later after we push it, after we take your stuff. What's your reaction to all of this, Kevin?

KEVIN WALLING, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: Sure, Liz. I'm so happy we're shining a light on this. And I couldn't agree with Ford more that it's the Wild West.

You know, Mark Zuckerberg testified before Congress last April. It's clear we need him back as soon as possible to answer some of these questions. If not, Congress you're also seeing a dip in terms of their stock value, down 20 percent.

So clearly, consumers are concerned about privacy issues, about regulatory issues regarding Facebook. So, if Congress doesn't get them to the table, hopefully consumers will push them to become better citizens when it comes to these issues.

MACDONALD: Yes, you know, Kevin makes an important point, Ford, because -- let me back up. Facebook also let Cambridge Analytica read our Facebook messages. We don't know who else is reading our messages. This is really bad. Will the market fix it, or should government fix it?

O'CONNELL: Well, I don't know that the market is going to fix it, and I think that you're also raising another question, Liz, and that's very simple. And that is that, basically, data privacy is seen in America among voters on a bipartisan scale on both size of the aisle like pre-existing conditions.

And when we look over to the E.A. and what they're doing with data privacy, I think that's going to be a guide going forward. But remember, President Trump is not very big on regulation, and he wants to avoid the headaches of a monstrous piece of legislation like Dodd-Frank and its unintended consequences.

I see something very narrowly tailored working towards data privacy, and if that doesn't work, then you may have more government regulation. The idea is to put some brakes on big tech but not to clamp them down. Because, remember, Liz, they're also a big part of driving our economy and our jobs.

MACDONALD: Yes, that's an important point too. That Silicon Valley is a big economic growth driver. Kevin, you know, the level of debate is so impoverished in this country, that's what critics have been saying. The fact that big tech has been censoring conservative thought and discussions on policy, on economic policy when way back in the day we saw Ted Kennedy - - I will always say that Ted Kennedy and Chuck Schumer voted for the tax cuts.

We don't see those debates happening on Facebook or Google's social media. I mean, what is going on here with these algorithms built by liberal Silicon Valley, they're basically censoring conservative debate? It is ruining debate and ruining this democracy, that's what the polls are showing.

WALLING: Liz, I couldn't agree with you more. Listen, I'm a die-hard Democrat, that's why I come on this show, because I really love how you host it and give a voice to both sides where we can have a debate, where we can move forward as a country. Because I think that's where the majority of Americans are.

And it really should give us pause if there is that kind of censorship going which is why I support bipartisan efforts. You mentioned Senator Klobuchar and Senator Kennedy from Louisiana that are pushing forward with that very thing in the United States Senate.

MACDONALD: Well, this story is not going to go away. We're going to stay on it. Kevin and Ford, we're going to have you back on to debate it and talk about it. Thank you so much--

(CROSSTALK)

WALLING: Thanks, Liz.

O'CONNELL: Thank you, E-Mac.

MACDONALD: -- for your analysis and insights tonight. Good to see you, guys.

Now to the border and the latest on the caravan. Jeff Paul is there reporting live on the ground in Tijuana, Mexico. Jeff?

JEFF PAUL, FOX NEWS CHANNEL CORRESPONDENT: Yes, Elizabeth. A press conference just wrapped up with some members of that migrant caravan just a few moments ago, and they put out a list of things they'd like to see moving forward.

The one -- the two that stick out to me, one, an end to unjust deportations, the other being that they want an acceleration of the process of applying for asylum into the United States.

Now we've spent some time today talking with all sorts of different migrants who are out here, and we're getting mixed reactions from both. Some feel what happened on Sunday, that clash with border patrol, only makes the whole group look bad while others who were part of that march and part of that demonstration say that they're going to stick it out, and they're hoping to still maybe one day get into the United States. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE (through translator): I'm going to cross the United States whatever it is with these crutches. These crutches will not stop me from crossing that fence illegally or legally. But I do not intend to cross illegally if I am hopeful that they will give me the papers. Because the first thing is to ask for political asylum in the United States to enter legally.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

PAUL: Now, for the migrants out here, they can kind of play a couple different ways. One of the options is to stay here which has probably more than 5,000 people with overcrowding out into the street while they wait for a possible chance for asylum in the United States, but they are only accepting -- not processing -- a hundred applications a day, if that.

The other is to stay in Tijuana and possibly to try to get a work visa here. Or the third option is to head back to Central America which we are starting to see more people look into that, and we saw our first van head down there today with a few people who had just given up and saying they're going back home. Elizabeth?

MACDONALD: Jeff Paul in Tijuana, Mexico. Thank you so much for your reporting, sir. Great reporting there. Good to see you.

Later in the show we will bring on Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton who will join us to talk about the battle in D.C. over funding the border wall the president wants, and also the government data showing the Obama administration used tear gas and pepper spray numerous times at the border. The debate on the media cover coverage of that coming up.

Also, this and other headlines, new information coming out of that black box from that Lion Air jet that crashed off of Indonesia last month. It reveals the airplane's pilots heroically fought to regain control of the plane 24 times in a short 11-minute period.

The pilots were fighting anti-stall software made by Boeing. That software pushed the Boeing jets nose of the plane down about two dozen times. The pilots fought to bring it back up, and that plane crash killed 189 people. We're staying on that story for you.

And look at this stunning footage. A sand wall 100 meters high overtook China's Zhangye City. It's a crazy video. Sandstorms are common in China, but local areas say they've never seen anything like this or this big.

Plus, look at this life-size model of Noah's Ark. The architect, Johan Huibers, he wants to sell that boat, that Noah's Ark, basically, type vessel to Israel. He believes God's ship should be on God's land. We're staying on that story for you. Fun stuff there.

Coming up, the Russia/Ukraine crisis now escalating. We'll have more on this later in the show with retired general Robert Scales.

But first, President Trump firing back at G.M. for planning to close multiple factories. The president saying, G.M., you better shape up or face financial pain, you may lose your federal government subsidies. We're going to deal with that next. And debate on whether Trump is now putting a stop to crony capitalism once and for all. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Welcome back. We're almost coming into the bottom of the hour. President Trump now threatening to cut all federal subsidies to General Motors including for G.M.'s electric cars after G.M. announced it will lay about, plans to lay off about 14,800 of its workers and shutter five factories in North America.

Deirdre Bolton has the latest. Deirdre?

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Hey, Liz. So, if we take a look at what the president tweeted out earlier, we will see his frustration. We're going to show it on the screen. "Very disappointed in G.M., very disappointed in the CEO, Mary Barra, for closing plants in Ohio, Michigan, and Maryland."

So, it is unclear, you mentioned this cessation of benefits, but it's unclear just how much G.M. benefits from federal government subsidies. It is also, quite frankly, unclear how the administration could restrict credit.

But the tweet does escalate the president's public threats against G.M. as he pushes this company to keep the facilities open in Ohio in Michigan and Maryland. He has repeatedly pressured American companies, we remember Harley Davidson who considered shutting down facilities or moving operations overseas after he pledged on the campaign trail to revive U.S. manufacturing.

Now, G.M. did put out its own statement, we're going to put that on the screen as well so you can follow. I'll just read part of it. But G.M. is committed to maintaining a strong manufacturing presence in the U.S. as evidenced by our more than $22 billion worth of investment in U.S. operations since 2009.

The company also talks about adding technical and engineering jobs, saying it appreciates the support it has from this administration. But I think, Liz, it's worth pointing out that G.M. is no longer only competing with a traditional carmaker such as Ford.

The company is facing pressure from a lot of the Silicon Valley upstarts, from Tesla, from Uber, from Apple, from Google. All of those companies want to make self-driving cars, all of those companies want to make electric cars. And I guess the sum total, self-driving electric ones.

So, G.M. does have a lot of pressure, and Mary Barra, the CEO, saying these moves are made to reinvent the company and keep it alive.

MACDONALD: Great reporting, Deirdre. We love having you on. Come back soon.

Let's bring in an expert. Her name is Veronique de Rugy. She's brilliant, she's at the Mercatus Center, she's also a syndicated columnist. We -- Veronique de Rugy there. There you are. Veronique, we don't know what federal subsidies the White House is talking about. There's a plug-in tax credit that goes to consumers for electric cars, but I want to -- I want to have this conversation with you, Veronique.

We know that G.M. got, you know, billions, tens of billions of dollars in bailout money. Why can't these automakers retool their factories to build either small cars or big cars like trucks and SUVs?

VERONIQUE DE RUGY, SENIOR RESEARCH FELLOW, GEORGE MASON UNIVERSITY MERCATUS CENTER: Well, I mean, you know me, I'm against those bailouts that G.M. and other automakers got, and I think it's not the role of the government to interfere in the production lines or the behavior and whatever production decision companies are making.

And they should be -- and it's actually good practice, it seems to me that G.M. is actually doing the right thing which is looking at the market of your future in cars and saying this is what we need to do. And, obviously, they should be doing it without subsidies.

MACDONALD: Yes, that's the point. Because you can, you know, people can understand the president's frustration here. Let me back up. U.S. taxpayers lost $11 billion on the 2008 bailout of G.M., and you know what happened then was that oil prices spiked up, and nobody wanted G.M.'s big cars and trucks at that time.

Oil prices and gas prices go down, now people want the big cars, they can afford it. They don't want the littler cars. So why can't G.M. and the carmakers get a grip on where gas prices are going? I think the president is frustrated because he knows that carmakers can come with their tin cups to federal taxpayers and get bailouts. He doesn't want it anymore.

DE RUGY: Well, I mean, government intervention into private businesses create massive distortions. It's bad for everyone, and consumers and taxpayers obviously, but it's also never quite great for the companies getting them because it actually push them -- pushes them into behaviors that are actually not necessarily efficient, and they're just out to seek - - to seek subsidies.

That being said, I would welcome the president cutting all subsidies to all companies, but I don't think this is what he is trying to do right now. He's frustrated, and he's using the threat of removing subsidies for this particular company as a threat against it.

And I think that has really just not proper for a president to do this.

MACDONALD: I hear -- no, I hear what you're saying, and let's do the back story here. We know that the bailout of the carmakers is often a bailout of the unions. We understand that.

DE RUGY: Yes, of course.

MACDONALD: We get that. And we know that these, you know, carmakers operate in important swing states for elections.

DE RUGY: Yes.

MACDONALD: That's the back story too. The question is, are the carmakers getting too lazy in fixing their own operations because they know they can come to the federal taxpayer? In other words, build factories you can immediately retool to build the cars that are in accordance--

DE RUGY: Yes.

MACDONALD: -- with gas prices going up or down.

DE RUGY: I completely agree with you. And the problem is a lot of these subsidies actually lead to what we call mal investment.

MACDONALD: Right, that's it.

DE RUGY: basically, you spend a lot of time going after subsidies and investing money because you want the subsidies as opposed to actually really thinking about what's best for your company.

And it does seem though -- and, obviously, the bailout was part of this, I'm sorry. It is not the role of a government at the federal level or at the state level to go and bail out companies if they're not selling products that consumers want to buy. They shouldn't be bailed out.

MACDONALD: Yes.

DE RUGY: They should go under, and, or they should revamp their model, you know? They will have a dry patch or whatever, but this practice is not productive, it doesn't lead to an auto sector that is actually productive--

MACDONALD: Yes.

DE RUGY: -- and competitive.

MACDONALD: Yes.

DE RUGY: And that is one of the problems.

MACDONALD: Veronique, you're great. All of a sudden G.M. says it can move workers that are going to be lay off to other factories. I don't understand how Mercedes can suddenly retool it existing car plants to make electric vehicles. If they can do it, well, why can't the other carmakers? Veronique, you're great. Great to see you. Come back soon, we love having you on.

DE RUGY: Yes.

MACDONALD: Coming up, we've got details on how the media botched the coverage of the tear gas used at the border. They didn't cover its use under the Obama administration. We've got the numbers coming up.

Plus, a new House hearing is expected in a couple of weeks on the Justice Department's probe into pay to play at the Clinton Foundation after new data shows donations there are plummeting after Hillary lost.

And the CDC now confirming 116 cases of polio-like paralysis in the United States. More on that with Doc Siegel coming up next. Stay there.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Welcome back. A mysterious polio-like disease that causes paralysis is now spreading to 31 states, sickening at least 116 children. With me now is Fox News medical correspondent Dr. Marc Siegel. Doctor, flu- like symptoms, what is causing this disease and how can you stop it?

MARC SIEGEL, MEDICAL CORRESPONDENT, FOX NEWS: I think it's a virus, and CDC thinks it's a virus, but it may be more than one strain of a virus called an enterovirus which is -- polio is an enterovirus, but it's not polio. It's a different kind of enterovirus, not polio. Polio-like.

Now, how could it be a virus and not spread from you to me? Let me tell you how. It's a very common virus, but it only causes this problem a very small amount of the time.

MACDONALD: How do you get it?

SIEGEL: Well, it goes around like wildfire --

MACDONALD: How would I get it?

SIEGEL: You'll get this virus just by sneezing, coughing, touching things. There are thousands and thousands of cases around the United States of the virus. But then this complication, again, only 117 cases and probably total almost 300 cases by the time --

MACDONALD: A lot of children are getting it.

SIEGEL: That's right. So 90 percent of the time, it's under the age of 18. The average age is four years old.

MACDONALD: How terrifying.

SIEGEL: I can't make light of something that affects 200 --

MACDONALD: No, we're not making light. Is there a vaccine for this? I mean, how do you stop it?

SIEGEL: Great question, Liz. If we knew which strain of enterovirus it was, we could do a vaccine. They have a vaccine, EV-68, which is one of the possible causes. But it's like the breadcrumbs. You see the breadcrumbs, you see the trail, but you're not exactly able to prove it. By the time they find this condition, evidence of the virus is already gone. So they can't prove it, so they don't want to --

MACDONALD: Understood. OK. Because Colorado is getting hit hard and Texas is getting hit hard, and there's been more than three and a half times the number of cases this year as last year, I mean, so, what would you advise parents out there to do?

SIEGEL: Well, I always want to decrease the fear quotient. I want to tell parents it's not contagious. I want to tell parents it's still one in a million cases --

MACDONALD: But we still don't know how you get it.

SIEGEL: No, we do know how you get it. You get it because you had a respiratory virus. So if your kid is coughing and sneezing, a few days later, they suddenly end up weak, you should be on the lookout for that. So do you should look for signs of weakness following a respiratory infection --

MACDONALD: Like flu-like symptoms.

SIEGEL: Right. You get flu-like symptoms, you get muscle aches, you get respiratory congestion, you get fever and then, bam, you're weak, upper or lower body weakness. Very tragic but still rare.

MACDONALD: I want to switch to this report. This is astonishing. Sleep apnea devices that people wear at night to help them sleep, millions of people wear it. Well, apparently these devices, doctor, are secretly spying on people. Can you explain this one?

SIEGEL: This is really horrifying. First of all, I want to tell you that, as you say, millions have this condition, and I want to tell you it can lead to strokes, it can lead to heart attacks, it can lead to diabetes --

MACDONALD: So the device.

SIEGEL: This is a really scary disease. You have to wear the machines. They reverse it. They're really important. But guess what, the machine can see how long you've been wearing it. The machine has a way of seeing whether you have the device on or not.

It monitors the number of hours you have it on. And guess what's happening, insurers are looking to see whether you're wearing it or not. And if you're not wearing, they're cutting off the reimbursement --

MACDONALD: Wait, wait, wait. The device is transmitting the information to the device maker, the medical supplier and the insurer to see if you're wearing the device or not?

SIEGEL: Wirelessly.

MACDONALD: Wow! So you're wearing it at night and you don't even know that this company, the insurer is looking at you to see if you're wearing it to cut up your coverage, is that the story?

SIEGEL: They're monitoring you, Liz.

MACDONALD: Even in your sleep.

SIEGAL: And what are they going to monitor next? Look at those brain waves. I mean, this is big brother. I think that -- my strong view is this goes too far. I'm OK with your doctor having this information, but I don't want your insurer having this. An invasion of the home. You can't even sleep anymore!

MACDONALD: I know.

(LAUGHTER)

MACDONALD: Good god. I mean, now -- I can't believe that they've gone that far. Can you believe that? I was shocked.

SIEGEL: I think they should be illegal. I don't think they should be able to cut off your coverage by saying you didn't wear the machine. The machines are extremely important medically.

MACDONALD: Yeah.

SIEGEL: They should be worn. Insurers, stay out of the bedroom.

MACDONALD: Oh, my god. No kidding.

(LAUGHTER)

MACDONALD: And the government too. Thank you, Doc Siegel. Good to see you. Great stuff.

Coming up, will President Trump get his $5 billion for his border wall? Big, high-level meetings in Washington today. A government shutdown looms less than two weeks away possibly. We're on it.

But first, Russia and the Ukraine clashing at sea. The stakes are high. What will President Trump do? How will Russian President Vladimir Putin react? We're bringing in retired Army Major General Robert Scales. He joins me next. Stay there. Back in two.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Tensions between Russia and the Ukraine reaching a boiling point. Three captured Ukrainian sailors forced to make statements on Russian state TV after Russian forces shot at and seized three Ukrainian naval ships over the weekend.

And this just in, breaking news, in an interview with The Washington Post, President Trump is now threatening to cancel his scheduled meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin at the G20 summit coming up because of Russia's clash at sea with the Ukraine.

Let's take it up with retired Major General Robert Scales. He's a Fox News contributor. Great to see you, general.

ROBERT SCALES, CONTRIBUTOR, FOX NEWS: Hi, Liz.

MACDONALD: What's your take on all of this?

SCALES: Well, it's just Vladimir Putin being Vladimir Putin, Liz. Although it didn't make the news, it's important to understand this is the fourth provocation by Putin this year. One over Finnish airspace (ph), one in the Baltic states where sea maneuvers (ph) were suspended, and of course we have the gas attack in Great Britain.

So this is Vladimir Putin trying to poke at the west. He hates the west, he hates the United States in particular. You know, there's an old staying, Lenin once said if you probe with a bayonet and you hit steel, stop. If you probe with a bayonet and hit mush, continue. Frankly, all Vladimir Putin's hits since the invasion of Georgia in 2008 is mush.

It's time for the president to take -- to take action, to push back against Putin. Otherwise, his brash acts will continue for as long as he's in office, Liz.

MACDONALD: So, what will President Trump do? Because we know President Vladimir Putin is probably watching Trump's response closely.

(LAUGHTER)

MACDONALD: So, what makes this risky for the U.S.? What do you think Trump should do?

SCALES: Several things. First of all, he's got to call out Putin personally. This isn't the Russian state doing this, this isn't their ministry of information doing it, it's Putin. It's very personal.

Number two, you have to hit back at Putin with acts that affect him personally. What does that include? Well, it includes anything that demeans him in the eyes of his own people. What would that be? Well, OK, how about increasing sanctions against Putin's inner circle? How about maneuvers with the Ukrainian army in the Ukraine by NATO forces?

That would send a terrific signal to Russia that the United States won't stand up for this. And if everything continues to fall apart in the Black Sea, perhaps even the entry of the Black Sea with American naval forces sometime in the future. Those are just a few things, active things that need to be done to stop this.

MACDONALD: Yeah. We've had General Jack Keane on, he would agree with you. He's also saying the media is not reporting that Trump is acting with a spine of steel against Russia with sanctions and the like, that the president has been tough on Russia.

Here's the thing, Russia just finished in the spring building this bridge connecting it, Russia to Crimea, so it controls the Kerch Strait and also the trade that's going on between the Black Sea and Azov Sea. I mean, Russia is full on threatening Ukraine right now. Is there a threat of full- out war between Russian and Ukraine right now?

SCALES: No.

MACDONALD: No?

SCALES: No, no, no. The Russian Black Sea fleet is a joke. It's -- what do they have? They have seven surface vessels and six conventional submarines. They have no naval power in the Black Sea. And if we were to float an amphibious ready group into the Black Sea full of marines and surface ships, it would embarrass Putin enormously because there is nothing he could do about it.

No, this is not about war, this is about information warfare and the use of the social media by a weak Russian military to face off against the United States. After all, Liz, Russia's got, what, it's got a GDP of, what, Texas?

(LAUGHTER)

SCALES: And yet in the eyes of the world, the Russians are portraying themselves as a superpower equal to the United States --

MACDONALD: Well, yeah.

SCALES: It's time for us to stand up militarily and humiliate Putin where he's weakest, and that's in the world of public opinion.

MACDONALD: It's a great point, general. I think the entire market value of Russia's stock market is equal to the market value of one company and that would be Apple. General, we'd love to have you back on, and we want to thank you for coming on the show. Thank you for your service to our country, sir. You brought great insight there and perspective. Good to see you.

SCALES: Thank you, Liz.

MACDONALD: Coming up, we'll ask Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton all about that funding fight happening now over the border wall. A government shutdown looms over it. Attorney General Paxton has a better read on the situation than just about anybody.

And we've got details on how the media botched the coverage of the tear gas at the border. Under the Obama administration, tear gas was used at least 27 times, pepper spray at least 434 times at the border. That's according to government data.

Plus, a new House hearing coming in a couple weeks on the Justice Department probe into pay to play at the Clinton Foundation. New details showing donations plummeting after Hillary lost. What took the Republicans so long on this? All of that's coming up. Back in two. Stay there.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: House Republican leaders sitting down with President Trump today to talk government shutdown over the border wall. Let's take it up with Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton. Great to see you, sir.

KEN PAXTON, TEXAS ATTORNEY GENERAL: Thanks for having me on.

MACDONALD: Quickly, I want your take, first, on the use of tear gas at the border. Under the Obama administration, tear gas was used at least 27 times, pepper spray used at least 434 times under Obama. That's according to government data. What's your take on the media coverage of the tear gas at the border as it relates to Obama's use of it?

PAXTON: I'm not surprised that they are covering it now. It's a legitimate use of tear gas to protect our border, and as long as they use it appropriately, I don't have a problem with it.

MACDONALD: OK, let's get back to the border wall funding. What number will President Trump be happy with? It's somewhere between $5 billion now and $1.6 billion. That's the Senate's number.

PAXTON: Yeah. And I don't know what his exact number is. I just know that his goal is to get the job done to make sure that we have a border wall that protects our country.

You know, even just starting off at the lower number, I think we're making progress. Hopefully, it's somewhere between the low number and the top number. In Texas, obviously, it's a huge issue for us and has been for years.

MACDONALD: You know conservatives have been blocking the border wall funding, saying DACA recipient -- citizenship is amnesty. Here's the other thing, sir, let's get to the migrants making a big mistake. Even though they're trying to seek asylum in the U.S., this migrants out of "credible fear," the migrants have to explain why they did not accept asylum in Mexico if it's really about credible fear. Why didn't they apply for asylum in Mexico?

PAXTON: You know, you're asking a really good question that I don't think I have the answer to other than that may not be the reason they're actually seeking asylum. Obviously, if you have a credible fear and you are at risk of being hurt in your own country, it would seem that you would take asylum from any country that would offer it. So it is a good question, and I don't think we actually know the answer.

MACDONALD: OK. MSNBC host Chris Matthews saying most caravan migrants are not eligible for asylum. Let's watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHRIS MATTHEWS, HOST, MSNBC: So, how do we regulate -- regulate, honestly, in an American way, acceptance of asylum seekers? How do we develop a profound, comprehensive immigration policy that we are proud of as Americans to enforce? At some point, there's going to have to be enforcement.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: There are people looking for jobs. That's not a basis to seek political asylum --

MATTHEWS: I know that.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: That's the law.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: That is a law, OK. And another MSNBC reporter, Mr. Paxton, basically saying the same thing, you can't come here looking for jobs under the asylum laws. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Give us a profile of who is there mostly.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The majority of them are men.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: They're men seeking jobs. We had to cut that sound bite. Finally, liberal media getting up to date and that is the speed on the asylum laws? Your take on that, sir.

PAXTON: No, it's actually kind of nice to hear. That's the reality. Asylum is for a very special class of people, people who are endangered in their own countries who are being persecuted, not for people looking for better economic opportunities. That process is the normal immigration process that these people should be following. Obviously, many of them have heard about this loophole, and they're taking advantage of it.

MACDONALD: All right. We're sorry we had to cut that second MSNBC sound bite.

PAXTON: No problem.

MACDONALD: We're going to try to show it to you in full tomorrow night. They were talking about the asylum laws covering -- not covering economic reasons, meaning job seekers. Thank you Attorney General Ken Paxton. We want to have you back on, sir. Great to see you.

PAXTON: Thank you.

MACDONALD: Coming up, the details on the democrat ballot plan against President Trump. Once Nancy Pelosi gavels in, that caucus vote coming tomorrow.

Also, we're going to stay on the story of the tear gas use at the border and how the media botched it. Again, dozens of times, tear gas used under the Obama administration. Pepper spray, hundreds of times. That's a government data.

We're also going to get into the Clinton pay to play probe at the Justice Department. That hearing is coming up in the House. We got that story, next. Stay there.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RUSH LIMBAUGH, RADIO TALK SHOW HOST AND CONSERVATIVE POLITICAL COMMENTATOR: A lot of Americans do not have the slightest idea who the Democrats really are. They still think the Democrats are the ones with compassion and tolerance and understanding. They still think the Democrats are the ones that care about the little guy and the downtrodden.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Well, the Democrat caucus vote for House speaker is tomorrow. Pelosi will likely be the winner. You can expect Pelosi then to go push full on government entitlements like Medicare and ignore everything that Trump asked for. Don't let Trump dominate the conversation. Ignore him. Also try to impeach him.

Let's ask Fox News contributor Jason Chaffetz on all of that. Your take on that, Jason. Great to see you.

JASON CHAFFETZ, CONTRIBUTOR, FOX NEWS: I think you're right on the policy side. This vote is fascinating because what they should do is publicly release how many people actually voted for her and then they've got to inquire and figure out who those people are. She'll undoubtedly win the majority but you have to have 218 votes on the floor of the House, not just behind closed doors.

MACDONALD: Let's get to that border fight over the use of tear gas. I'm staying on this one. Because under the Obama administration, tear gas was used at least 27 times. It was used 27 times in 2012 and 1016. Pepper spray used 432 times during that time period. What's your take on the media coverage of that?

CHAFFETZ: I would pose the question to the Democrats saying what do you propose? People are crashing our borders, they're throwing rocks, they're waving the flags of the countries they came from. These are not the people that are truly trying to seek asylum. They don't meet any of those qualifications.

So if you're going to be overrun, the most humane thing to do is to use the tear gas. And these people made a conscious decision as to whether or not they were going to have this type of response from the United States. We're not supposed to roll over that, but the media, so irresponsible to just blame it and try to make Trump look like the bad guy that they want him to be. He's not. He's doing exactly what he's supposed to be doing, enforcing the border.

MACDONALD: And no hollering when the President Obama administration did it. I want your take on the Clinton Foundation donation, nearly 63 million suddenly plummeting to less than $27 million a year later in 2017. Mark Meadows, chair of the Oversight Committee, he wants hearings on this. What's taken Republicans to long to get a hearing on the pay to play allegations at the Clinton Foundation? We got the U.S. attorney looking into it at Justice Department.

CHAFFETZ: You need the Department of Justice to provide Mark Meadows and the Oversight Committee, a committee I used to chair, they got to provide him the documents. Where has been this investigation? Where are these documents from the Department of Justice?

It's really hard to do a proper hearing without that document. And no matter who is the president, it's really hard to get the deep state folks there at the Department of Justice to cough up these documents.

MACDONALD: Your quick take on the Clinton Foundation donations plummeting after Hillary lost.

CHAFFETZ: Come on, she is no longer going to be a viable political figure. It doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure out that there was a lot of pay to play there. They were trying to (INAUDIBLE) themselves to Hillary Clinton, and now she is a book author and not much else to do.

MACDONALD: Jason Chaffetz, we love having you on. Sir, come back soon.

CHAFFETZ: Thank you.

MACDONALD: Well, it was a jam-packed hour. Thank you so much for watching. Thank you for having us in your homes. We've got "LOU DOBBS" next right here on the Fox Business Network. Have a good night.

END

Announced It's Going to Lay Off about 14,800 of Its Workers and Close Down Plants in North America; Polio-Like Disease that Causes Paralysis is Now Spreading to 31 States, Sickening at Least 116 Children; Trump Threatens to Cancel Putin Meeting over Clash with Ukraine; Russia Detains Ukrainian Sailors after a Clash at Sea; Trump Pushes for $5 billion in Border Wall Funding; Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton Discusses How the U.S. Border Patrol Used Tear Gas on Migrants Attempting to Rush the U.S.-Mexico Border and President Trump's Push for Border Wall Funding; Fox News Contributor Jason Chaffetz on House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi's Push to Become House Speaker and How the U.S. Border Patrol Used Tear Gas on Migrants Attempting to Rush the Southern BorderLanhamFULL TEXT

(JOINED IN PROGRESS)

DAVID ASMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Thanks for joining us. "EVENING EDIT" starts right now.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We know from a recent investigation by "The New York Times" that Facebook was aware as a company much, much earlier that these ads were being placed and run.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Any information you can see contained within that cache of e-mails was, at best, partial. And at worst, potentially misleading.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This information can use public domain about keep the company's knowledge because of a separate investigation, not in the multiple hearings that the company has attended where they've been asked these questions.

They didn't report it to anyone at the time, and during the period when we were asking questions about it, no one disclosed that the company was aware of this information earlier.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I do want to set that context, and those e-mailed are unverified, partial accounts from a source who has a particular angle.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Wow, that was a heated exchange at a hearing in the U.K. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg a no-show at that major international hearing in Great Britain to answer new bombshell charges. It goes from bad to worse at Facebook.

We dig in to the stunning new allegations out of the U.K. based on Facebook e-mails the U.K. had seized. That Facebook was warned about Russians trolling through Facebook, harvesting your information much earlier than realized starting way back in 2014. Up to three billion data points a day.

This as U.S. senators here in this country warn Facebook may have broken the law. We explain.

Also coming up, Google now under fire by seven countries in Europe who now say Google is still secretly tracking you even after you turn it off. And that Google tricks you into giving it much more information about yourself and your families, more than you realize all without your consent.

This as Google workers now demand Google must stop building a censored search engine for China that that China can use to attract and arrest citizens that commit human rights violations. Protests worldwide on that, we're on it.

Also coming up to Capitol Hill, high-level meetings over the border wall funding. Will President Trump get what he wants, and wat is that poison pill that will cause Republican conservatives to defeat it?

Plus, details tonight on the new Republican push for results from that Justice Department probe into the Clinton Foundation. New details showing donations plummeting after Hillary lost the election. Republicans say that's proof that the Clintons engaged in pay to play.

Well, thank you so much for joining us, thank you for watching. Money, politics, we've got the debate behind tomorrow's headlines. I'm Elizabeth MacDonald. THE EVENING EDIT starts right now.

Welcome to the show. You're watching the Fox Business Network.

Over 100 Google workers publishing an open letter today, slamming Google, demanding it stop building a censored search engine for China. It's designed to possibly blacklist words like human rights or student protests. Fear is that China will use that Google search engine to arrest its own citizens and commit even more human rights violations.

Hillary Vaughn has the details. Hillary?

HILLARY VAUGHN, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Hi, Liz. Well, these Google engineers really are teaming up to take on Google, trying to get them to shut down the development of this dragonfly search engine. The Googlers pending a public letter. The list of signatories has been growing throughout the day.

The letter calling out Google for putting what they call profits over their own company's values that are supposed to include basic human rights.

The letter writing, quote, "Dragonfly in China would establish a dangerous precedent at a volatile political moment, one that would make it harder for Google to deny other countries similar concessions, providing the Chinese government with ready access to user data as required by Chinese law would make Google complicit in oppression and human rights abuses."

This is not the first time Googlers have sounded off about this product. The letter says thousands internally at Google have protested the tools. Many of these people that signed on to this letter are engineers, and they say they should have a say how the tools that they are building are being used and by who is using them.

Dragonfly would ramp up surveillance of Chinese citizens, sparking concerns that the government would use Google's data to silence dissenters, censor unpopular points of view, these are concerns that -- or there are concerns that the data would also make Chinese citizens less safe.

So, Google's been dealing with a lot of backlash about this not internally but also publicly too. Lawmakers on Capitol Hill, even vice President Mike pence calling for Google to stop the development of this product.

But each time Google has offered this same very statement that they wrote months ago, even though the letter today was published this morning, saying that their work on search in China is just exploratory, and they're not ready to launch anything soon, so we'll have to wait and see if Google decides to address publicly some of these concerns by their own employees.

But they're not the only tech company in the spotlight here. What's your take on the media coverage of the tear gas at the border as it relates to Obama's use of it?

PAXTON: I'm not surprised that they are covering it now. It's a legitimate use of tear gas to protect our border, and as long as they use it appropriately, I don't have a problem with it.

MACDONALD: OK, let's get back to the border wall funding. What number will President Trump be happy with? It's somewhere between $5 billion now and $1.6 billion. That's the Senate's number.

PAXTON: Yeah. And I don't know what his exact number is. I just know that his goal is to get the job done to make sure that we have a border wall that protects our country.

You know, even just starting off at the lower number, I think we're making progress. Hopefully, it's somewhere between the low number and the top number. In Texas, obviously, it's a huge issue for us and has been for years.

MACDONALD: You know conservatives have been blocking the border wall funding, saying DACA recipient -- citizenship is amnesty. Here's the other thing, sir, let's get to the migrants making a big mistake. Even though they're trying to seek asylum in the U.S., this migrants out of "credible fear," the migrants have to explain why they did not accept asylum in Mexico if it's really about credible fear. Why didn't they apply for asylum in Mexico?

PAXTON: You know, you're asking a really good question that I don't think I have the answer to other than that may not be the reason they're actually seeking asylum. Obviously, if you have a credible fear and you are at risk of being hurt in your own country, it would seem that you would take asylum from any country that would offer it. So it is a good question, and I don't think we actually know the answer.

MACDONALD: OK. MSNBC host Chris Matthews saying most caravan migrants are not eligible for asylum. Let's watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHRIS MATTHEWS, HOST, MSNBC: So, how do we regulate -- regulate, honestly, in an American way, acceptance of asylum seekers? How do we develop a profound, comprehensive immigration policy that we are proud of as Americans to enforce? At some point, there's going to have to be enforcement.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: There are people looking for jobs. That's not a basis to seek political asylum --

MATTHEWS: I know that.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: That's the law.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: That is a law, OK. And another MSNBC reporter, Mr. Paxton, basically saying the same thing, you can't come here looking for jobs under the asylum laws. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Give us a profile of who is there mostly.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The majority of them are men.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: They're men seeking jobs. We had to cut that sound bite. Finally, liberal media getting up to date and that is the speed on the asylum laws? Your take on that, sir.

PAXTON: No, it's actually kind of nice to hear. That's the reality. Asylum is for a very special class of people, people who are endangered in their own countries who are being persecuted, not for people looking for better economic opportunities. That process is the normal immigration process that these people should be following. Obviously, many of them have heard about this loophole, and they're taking advantage of it.

MACDONALD: All right. We're sorry we had to cut that second MSNBC sound bite.

PAXTON: No problem.

MACDONALD: We're going to try to show it to you in full tomorrow night. They were talking about the asylum laws covering -- not covering economic reasons, meaning job seekers. Thank you Attorney General Ken Paxton. We want to have you back on, sir. Great to see you.

PAXTON: Thank you.

MACDONALD: Coming up, the details on the democrat ballot plan against President Trump. Once Nancy Pelosi gavels in, that caucus vote coming tomorrow.

Also, we're going to stay on the story of the tear gas use at the border and how the media botched it. Again, dozens of times, tear gas used under the Obama administration. Pepper spray, hundreds of times. That's a government data.

We're also going to get into the Clinton pay to play probe at the Justice Department. That hearing is coming up in the House. We got that story, next. Stay there.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RUSH LIMBAUGH, RADIO TALK SHOW HOST AND CONSERVATIVE POLITICAL COMMENTATOR: A lot of Americans do not have the slightest idea who the Democrats really are. They still think the Democrats are the ones with compassion and tolerance and understanding. They still think the Democrats are the ones that care about the little guy and the downtrodden.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Well, the Democrat caucus vote for House speaker is tomorrow. Pelosi will likely be the winner. You can expect Pelosi then to go push full on government entitlements like Medicare and ignore everything that Trump asked for. Don't let Trump dominate the conversation. Ignore him. Also try to impeach him.

Let's ask Fox News contributor Jason Chaffetz on all of that. Your take on that, Jason. Great to see you.

JASON CHAFFETZ, CONTRIBUTOR, FOX NEWS: I think you're right on the policy side. This vote is fascinating because what they should do is publicly release how many people actually voted for her and then they've got to inquire and figure out who those people are. She'll undoubtedly win the majority but you have to have 218 votes on the floor of the House, not just behind closed doors.

MACDONALD: Let's get to that border fight over the use of tear gas. I'm staying on this one. Because under the Obama administration, tear gas was used at least 27 times. It was used 27 times in 2012 and 1016. Pepper spray used 432 times during that time period. What's your take on the media coverage of that?

CHAFFETZ: I would pose the question to the Democrats saying what do you propose? People are crashing our borders, they're throwing rocks, they're waving the flags of the countries they came from. These are not the people that are truly trying to seek asylum. They don't meet any of those qualifications.

So if you're going to be overrun, the most humane thing to do is to use the tear gas. And these people made a conscious decision as to whether or not they were going to have this type of response from the United States. We're not supposed to roll over that, but the media, so irresponsible to just blame it and try to make Trump look like the bad guy that they want him to be. He's not. He's doing exactly what he's supposed to be doing, enforcing the border.

MACDONALD: And no hollering when the President Obama administration did it. I want your take on the Clinton Foundation donation, nearly 63 million suddenly plummeting to less than $27 million a year later in 2017. Mark Meadows, chair of the Oversight Committee, he wants hearings on this. What's taken Republicans to long to get a hearing on the pay to play allegations at the Clinton Foundation? We got the U.S. attorney looking into it at Justice Department.

CHAFFETZ: You need the Department of Justice to provide Mark Meadows and the Oversight Committee, a committee I used to chair, they got to provide him the documents. Where has been this investigation? Where are these documents from the Department of Justice?

It's really hard to do a proper hearing without that document. And no matter who is the president, it's really hard to get the deep state folks there at the Department of Justice to cough up these documents.

MACDONALD: Your quick take on the Clinton Foundation donations plummeting after Hillary lost.

CHAFFETZ: Come on, she is no longer going to be a viable political figure. It doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure out that there was a lot of pay to play there. They were trying to (INAUDIBLE) themselves to Hillary Clinton, and now she is a book author and not much else to do.

MACDONALD: Jason Chaffetz, we love having you on. Sir, come back soon.

CHAFFETZ: Thank you.

MACDONALD: Well, it was a jam-packed hour. Thank you so much for watching. Thank you for having us in your homes. We've got "LOU DOBBS" next right here on the Fox Business Network. Have a good night.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X38-PSS1-F00X-J02B-00000-00Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg meets with Trump2019-09-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:45:28ZLexisNexisFacebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg meets with TrumpAnne Stanley

Facebook exec meets with president Thursday during a week in Washington as big tech companies face pressure from regulators and lawmakers.

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg met with President Trump at the White House on Thursday, during a trip to Washington to meet with policymakers about future tech regulation, according to published reports.

A report from CNBC quoted an unnamed Facebook spokesperson as saying Zuckerberg was "meeting with policymakers to hear their concerns and talk about future internet regulation. He also had a good, constructive meeting with President Trump at the White House today."

Jennifer Jacobs, senior White House reporter for Bloomberg News, tweeted that Dan Scavino, White House social media director, and Jared Kushner also were in the meeting.

Scoop: WH aides Dan Scavino and Jared Kushner joined Trump for the Facebook meeting. Scavino, who is Trump's social media director, is the WH aide who uses the platform the most. CEO Mark Zuckerberg trying to sway Congress and policy makers who have been critical of Facebook.

- Jennifer Jacobs (@JenniferJJacobs)

Facebook, along with Amazon , Apple and Alphabet is under scrutiny from regulators and lawmakers as leaders of both parties in the House Judiciary Committee have requested private communications from top executives and other detailed information about their individual internal operations.

Alphabet has been asked to turn over internal emails and other records related to its prior mergers, including its purchase of YouTube, as well as documents it has turned over to foreign governments in connection with previous antitrust probes of the company, according to the Washington Post.

Meanwhile, Facebook has been asked to turn over records of Zuckerberg's communications that may have discussed corporate rivals, including about companies they have since acquired such as Instagram and WhatsApp.

Trump has been critical of Facebook, as well as other tech companies, targeting Facebook's proposed digital currency, Libra, and also because the president says he believes the social media platform is biased against conservatives.


Facebook, Amazon, Apple and Alphabet are holdings in Jim Cramer's. Want to be alerted before Cramer buys or sells these stocks? .

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VTG-63F1-F19Y-C564-00000-00Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg's appeal for more regulation met with skepticism2019-04-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:45:28ZLexisNexisExclusiveFacebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg's appeal for more regulation met with skepticismAnna Akins

Several industry experts said the threat of increased regulation coming from outside Facebook likely influenced CEO Mark Zuckerberg's decision to make a call to action, including his endorsement of European-style privacy regulations.

Facebook Inc. CEO Mark Zuckerberg's call for tougher internet regulation drew skepticism from industry experts and lawmakers who noted the company's defensive posture after a series of high-profile privacy scandals and content regulation concerns.

In an op-ed published March 30, Zuckerberg said regulators must take "a more active role" in developing laws around four areas: harmful content, election integrity, privacy and data portability. The company is taking public input on its plan to launch a new oversight body to assist with content moderation. But several industry experts and lawmakers said the growing threat of increased regulation coming from outside Facebook likely influenced Zuckerberg's decision to make a public call to action, including his endorsement of European-style privacy regulations.

Gene Munster, a managing partner at venture capital firm Loup Ventures, which has a focus on technology, said Zuckerberg's op-ed was a good public relations move, but it does not address larger questions regarding Facebook's role in society. Munster agreed with Zuckerberg that government should set some "guidelines" around how Facebook and its tech peers operate, but he said it will be challenging to determine the appropriate level of regulation.

"These are the trees, but I think the forest question is, is the world a better place with Facebook? Do we even need Facebook?" Munster said in an interview.

Zuckerberg's comments March 30 mark the executive's strongest to date in support of government oversight of his company. Appearing before a U.S. congressional committee in April 2018, Zuckerberg signaled some support for stronger regulations on social media, but offered few specifics.

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg appears beforea U.S. congressional committee in April 2018.Source: Associated Press "My position is not that there should be no regulation," Zuckerberg said during a hearing in front of the U.S. Senate Judiciary and Commerce committees, adding, "I think the real question, as the internet becomes more important in people's lives, is what is the right regulation?"

In a separate hearing in September 2018, Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg said the company would work with Congress to reach "the right regulation."

Harmful content

Zuckerberg in his recent op-ed said that Facebook has a "responsibility to keep people safe," but the company's immense scale makes it difficult to adequately address all forms of harmful content, including "terrorist propaganda" and "hate speech." In one such example, the social media giant came under fire last month after the livestream of a gunman killing dozens of worshipers at two New Zealand mosques was uploaded on the platform before circulating throughout the wider internet.

The tech executive shared a similar message in April 2018 when he told U.S. legislators that Facebook did not take a "broad enough view" of its responsibility to prevent the spread of harmful content on the platform. Zuckerberg at the time also noted that Facebook had upped its defenses against such abuses, including developing more advanced artificial intelligence techniques to detect and delete fake accounts and hiring more security reviewers.

Sen. Mark Warner, D-Va., ranking member on the Senate Intelligence Committee, who has drafted several proposals for regulating big tech, responded to Zuckerberg's March 30 op-ed by urging Facebook to work with Congress on developing new policy. In an April 1 tweet, Warner said Facebook and its counterparts "are going to need to be subject to a higher level of regulation in keeping with their enormous power."

Regarding election integrity, Zuckerberg said March 30 that Facebook has made "significant changes" around political advertisements, including requiring political ad buyers to provide names and locations. Still, "we believe legislation should be updated to reflect the reality of the threats and set standards for the whole industry," including addressing ad targeting questions, Zuckerberg wrote.

Concerns about the role of Facebook's platforms in spreading misinformation campaigns during the 2016 U.S. presidential election have long dogged the company. COO Sandberg acknowledged during a September 2018 hearing before the Senate Intelligence Committee that her firm was "slow to spot" the foreign-backed misinformation campaigns during the 2016 U.S. election season.

Privacy protections

Zuckerberg said the U.S. and other countries should adopt rules similar to Europe's General Data Protection Regulation, a series of privacy laws that took effect in May of 2018. GDPR requires companies to obtain unambiguous affirmative consent from a user before collecting or processing the user's personal data, among other provisions.

"By updating the rules for the internet, we can preserve what's best about it the freedom for people to express themselves and for entrepreneurs to build new things while also protecting society from broader harms," Zuckerberg wrote.

Eric Goldman, a law professor at Santa Clara University who has expertise in internet law and intellectual property, said Zuckerberg's endorsement of European-style regulation is not surprising given that Facebook has robust financial resources to shoulder such requirements. Such rules would be more burdensome to smaller companies, Goldman added.

"[Facebook executives are] really tired of being yelled at for their decisions about content, so they just want somebody else, anyone else, even the government, to tell them what to do," Goldman said in an interview.

Rep. David Cicilline, D-R.I., who chairs the House Judiciary Committee's Subcommittee on Antitrust, Commercial and Administrative Law, responded to Zuckerberg's op-ed by saying more regulation of the company was long overdue. "[Facebook] has shown it cannot regulate itself," Cicilline said in a March 30 tweet.

value.Title: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg Stoked Washington's Fears About TikTok
