Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5S05-97V1-DY0W-43NV-00000-00Facebook CEO to Appear Before Congress; Census Controversy; Kim Jong-un Visiting China?; Dow Drops; California's Sanctuary City Fight2018-03-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:45:28ZLexisNexisFacebook CEO to Appear Before Congress; Census Controversy; Kim Jong-un Visiting China?; Dow Drops; California's Sanctuary City FightLanhamFULL TEXT

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

NEIL CAVUTO, HOST: In your Facebook.

Are investors freaking out because the government could be digging in and way beyond Facebook?

Welcome, everybody. I'm Neil Cavuto.

New fears right now that Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg might not be alone, that there are other tech companies that are getting caught up in the, hey, we're from the United States government and we would like to chat.

Nvidia plunging today after suspending self-driving tests. That's got local government interest. Tesla dropping to its lowest level in almost a year amid reports that the government is investigating a Tesla vehicle crash in California and wants to know what exactly happened.

Then there's the case of Microsoft, which was supposed to be the next trillion-dollar company. Reports now it was among the most poorly performing Dow stocks, and no one, no one is investigating Microsoft.

What is going on here with this widening concern in Washington that, you know, we'd like to get a handle on this? The problem with Washington wanting to get a handle on something is, well, sellers get a handle on selling and selling and selling. And by day's end, down about 334.5 points.

Now, keep in mind, we gained about 669 points yesterday, but this whipsawing, this volatility, as our Ashley Webster can tell you from FOX Business Network, has suddenly come back in vogue.

What happened?

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FOX NEWS BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: The investors are twitching out there, no doubt, Neil.

If it wasn't for the last hour of trading, we'd be fine. Right? Unless you're betting on these stocks going lower.

CAVUTO: Right.

WEBSTER: But my, oh, my, you can almost feel it, when this sail -- the selling of stocks starts to pick up momentum.

But you mentioned those big tech companies. Yes, we know that Facebook has privacy problems. We know that Nvidia, the big chip company, says it's going to stop or at least suspend its self-driving car testing.

But then, as you mentioned, Neil, Microsoft suddenly gets hit, is down more, as I see here, more than 4 percent on the day. That is what you call indiscriminate selling. That is guilty by association. And it brings down a whole sector.

And, as we know, tech has led the way for these markets for so long. But, boy, oh, boy, you start taking -- you start talking about regulation that could impact business models, that could impact earnings, and all of a sudden they're running for the exits.

But it's not just tech today, Neil. We also saw the financials getting hit, as we saw that 10-year yield on the treasury actually breaking below 2.8 percent. In other words, it was a bond rally, a run to safety. That means lower rates and that hurts the banks. The banks also got hit and swept up in this big selling rush, if you like.

As you can see, the 10-year yield down to 2.79. It was at 2.9 something just a week ago. Down another more than five basis points. So, in other words, we're seeing a trend. Yesterday, we were up 600 points. Down today 344 points on the Dow. Is this the new normal? Analysts say yes.

But we do get earnings, first-quarter earnings, next month. Maybe that will calm some of the nerves, Neil. But, my goodness, once we get into that 2:45, 3:00 hour, it's truly the witching hour every day.

CAVUTO: It certainly seems to be.

Now, I know the biggest concern right now is that it's not just Facebook, that the government is interested in talking to the folks behind Twitter and Google and all of this just to get an idea of how they start collecting information on us.

WEBSTER: Right.

CAVUTO: And the intentions might be fine, but Wall Street generally abhors government looking into anything, doesn't it?

WEBSTER: Well, it's that Reagan comment, isn't it, I'm from the government and I'm here to help you. That's the most terrifying thing you can hear.

And once you get regulations, generally, Washington doesn't do regulations, it's never going to be a positive. And certainly when it comes to these big tech companies, Neil, that means reduced margins, not making as much money, more transparency. I understand all of that.

But from a purely business point of view, that could spell bad news for these very fast-growing companies.

CAVUTO: All right, thank you very much, my friend. A very nice wrap-up of a crazy day, Ashley Webster.

Just you hear this term volatility. And it used to mean just swings of 1 percent or more. And we saw very, very few of those, certainly last year. In fact, putting it in perspective here, we have already doubled the number of 1 percent moves in this early year. We're not even done with the first quarter, right? More than double what we had all of last year, and that's just a preview, we're told, of coming attractions.

To Jonas Max Ferris, John Tamny, Bob Iaccino.

Bob, end it with you, begin with you.

Is it your sense that, besides the drama of the last hour, that the Street is worrying about a government fix for what happened or what was allowed to happen at Facebook and that it extends beyond Facebook? So a lot of your colleagues, not you, mind you, freak out?

(LAUGHTER)

BOB IACCINO, PATH TRADING PARTNERS: Yes, I think that's definitely what it is, Neil. That's what's happening, as you talk about Mark Zuckerberg potentially testifying.

He's awkward on stage at his own pre-prepared speeches. I think Congress, quite frankly, with a bank of lawyers, would absolutely shred him and it's going to look bad.

So, I definitely think that's what Wall Street is looking at. And from the volatility perspective, we just had an unprecedented run, a decades-low run, where the average daily range of the equity markets was about 0.8 percent. And historically that kind of run in low volatility is followed by a run of high volatility.

You might looking at six to nine months of these kinds of moves.

CAVUTO: You know, John Tamny, when look at this, we were heralding a little more than 24 hours ago, actually, a little more than two hours ago, this notion that the president will get his way on these tariffs that the Chinese are blinking on, that they're going to concede something, give something.

Either buy more semiconductor chips or that kind of thing to try to even the gap between our two countries. Good luck on pulling that off. But that this is bigger than trade. This has more to do with a sector that has led this rally that might be kind of coughing, right?

JOHN TAMNY, EDITOR, REALCLEARMARKETS: Well, yes.

When you look at like Microsoft and Facebook, you're looking at two of the five most valuable companies in the world. And so suddenly we're hearing about the possibility that regulation from Washington is on the way. Let's be clear about what that is.

We're talking about people who cannot get jobs at these companies suddenly having a say in how they're run. Is it any wonder that investors are spooked? Add to the fact that I think the markets are saying the only closed economy is the world economy. When you shut off China, you shut off the rest of the world for the U.S. to export to also.

CAVUTO: Yes, we talk about these extreme days, Jonas.

And I know you and I over the years have seen that, where one day an industry can be a darling. Suddenly, the next day, it's a pariah. Which is more accurate? The sell-off that we saw in technology particularly today or the run-up particularly in that sector yesterday?

JONAS MAX FERRIS, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Well, I think that fear is always there with technology. That's a sector that has fallen out of favor in the past.

CAVUTO: Absolutely.

FERRIS: It can just fall 50 percent. It's probably the single most risky sector because of innovation that goes on. Just the stocks get overprices and then people all of a sudden are not into them. We saw a lot of hot money going into these tech funds recently, just like in 1999 and 2000.

I think the fear really now here is just that. It's what kind of Ashley Webster was saying. They're fast-growing companies. Investors are worried they're formerly fast-growing companies. A lot of them were making money essentially spying on people and selling information off.

At least that's what it's going to look like to the government regulators when they finally see what is going on in Silicon Valley, an area that has gotten very little regulation compared to, say, Europe, where they're always shaking down these companies for something.

That might be happening or starting to happen here between the car crash, between Facebook with the election stuff and this. It's just they're just going to pounce and they're not going to like what they see, if they even understand it, and we might get a mishmash of rules that are going to bring this business model to a grinding halt for the companies that live off of it.

It's not everybody. It's more Facebook than like Apple, but these companies, they give you free stuff. It costs money to host all the servers where you put up your videos, and they make money by watching you. It's like having a community center and having microphones everywhere and recording people and selling that information to the highest bidder.

That's what the business model is going to look like to people in Congress who don't understand it or senators.

CAVUTO: Yes. I think you're a little cruel when you say they couldn't get a job at any of those companies. I think it's a little mean.

But I understand where all of you are coming from.

But, Bob, I'm looking at this and I'm wondering the pressure that suddenly is on Mark Zuckerberg right now. It's not only about trying to hold up his company and image and reputation.

Suddenly now, you have an entire industry that might be hanging on his every word, because while they'd love to see a competitor under duress, they're beginning to realize, hey, hey, we're in on this, too.

IACCINO: Well, to your point earlier, Neil, /I love the comments we have gotten so far out of this panel, because this is not really news that they have stolen your data.

I mean, Facebook has been stealing your data, Twitter's been stealing your data. Snapchat's doing it now. I'm not on any of those except Twitter because of that. It's not news that they have been making money off of your data.

And the average American doesn't seem to care about it. And when the government gets involved, I would much rather the government were regulating the NSA than they would be Facebook because people are voluntarily giving their data to Facebook in exchange for the platform use.

That's something that is in their terms and is pretty widely known.

CAVUTO: But I will tell you, you touch on something.

IACCINO: But you're right. It's the business model. It's the business model, Neil.

CAVUTO: Yes.

John, I'm reminded, I'm reminded -- that's a very good point.

I'm reminded of the view that Scott McNealy had, who used to run Sun Microsystems, that if you want your privacy, get over it in this day and age. I'm paraphrasing here, this notion that, with high technology and the convenience it brings you, whether it's Facebook or some of these other entities, you will surrender some of that.

And there will be incidents that come up now and then that will make you question, what's that balance? That is going to be driven into focus right now. And imagine, whether they're congressional hearings in the case of Facebook or FTC investigation looking at its books, that magnifying glass will be most unwelcome for this industry.

What do you think?

TAMNY: Well, McNealy got it right. But I will just add, in the case of Facebook, you got that for free. How do you think that Facebook was paying for itself, other than widely using your data?

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: No, you're absolutely right. You're absolutely.

TAMNY: And actually enhancing what it gives you precisely because it uses your data.

And so I think it's essential that Mark Zuckerberg remind Congress to mind its own business.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: I don't know. I don't know, because this extends to a Tesla, right?

When the government is looking into a crash that involves a Tesla vehicle a week or so back in California, on top of what Uber is saying, we're going to discontinue these driverless tests for a while, I think it's maybe bigger than any individual company. I just wonder where that goes.

Jonas, what do you think?

FERRIS: Neil, the business has evolved slowly, but questionably.

It used to be controversial to sell search ads that were based on your search traffic. Now that is like the least of their problems with what they're doing.

The problem is, this evolution probably needs to be fixed. I don't know if the government is going to be able to do it. They could hurt the industry.

CAVUTO: We will watch very closely.

Gentlemen, thank you. A last-second notice for all coming on here and trying to make sense of this crazy world. Good job, all.

Again, I think as we were pointing out earlier on here, there was sort of a safe haven run to bonds, to treasury notes, to something boring, because boring was cool today. I love days like this, because suddenly people like me are cool. That's what happened today. Boring was a draw. People went to bonds.

It was a safe place to park cash, and interest rates came down to 2.79 percent, even as they were selling off, actually because they were selling off at the corner of Wall and Broad.

We will stay on this, look at some of the other repercussions here and what some folks on Capitol Hill are considering when they get back from their vacation, because, boy, they are loaded for bear, and I'm not just talking bear market. We're on top of that.

Also on top of Kim Jong-un. Where the hell is he?

After this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DENZEL WASHINGTON, ACTOR: This is 1206 heading northbound on the main line.

UNIDENTIFIED ACTRESS: Why are you still on the main line?

WASHINGTON: We need to know the location of your yard's crane.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: Well, it's not just a runaway train, more like a mystery train. And everyone wants to know, on this mystery train, is a certain passenger named Kim Jong-un on it?

So we have got a possible secret meeting going on between China and North Korea. A lot of people are saying this, oddly enough, might have been propelled by those threatened tariffs and the likes of sanctions that are combining to produce an emergency powwow between North Korea and its biggest benefactor, the Chinese.

Former Press Secretary to Vice President Mike Pence Marc Lotter, also national security analyst Rebecca Grant.

Did that, particularly on the tariff front, propel this -- this move today? I mean, Rebecca, looking at what's going on, if Kim Jong-un is indeed in China, did the tariffs in a weird way force this?

REBECCA GRANT, NATIONAL SECURITY ANALYST: They might have.

But, you know, I don't really care who was on the train, whether it was Kim or his sister or Colonel Rhee, their negotiator, or one of the other North Korean officials. I'm just glad that someone was there.

If it's Kim, I think it's high time he got out. He needed a warm-up round. But this means to me that China is still very serious, wants to be a part of this. And hopefully there was some progress made in figuring out the big question, which is, what is Kim going to want to agree to real denuclearization?

CAVUTO: It could be added pressure, Marc, on the North Korean leader from, again, his chief benefactor, the Chinese, to say you got to behave, or, or these tariffs were just an elaborate subterfuge to get just what we're watching now.

I know that was Steve Bannon's argument when in New York the other day.

MARC LOTTER, FORMER PRESS SECRETARY FOR VICE PRESIDENT MIKE PENCE: I think whether it's the tariffs or whether it's just the ongoing maximum pressure campaign, it's showing that President Trump's leadership is working.

North Korea knows that it needs to make changes. China has already come to the table and severely cut back on their exports to North Korea, which is putting a real crimp in that country's economy.

So they needed to do something, and as he prepares to meet with the president, it's very important that they be on the same page. And it's good to see that hopefully that China is going to continue to work with the U.S. and President Trump in continuing that maximum pressure.

CAVUTO: Well, I don't know what's the genesis for what, so I will defer to both of you. But I do wonder if part of this is about trying to settle on a location for the North Korean leader and President Trump to meet.

The president can't meet in North Korea. I doubt even China is a logical venue. But what do you think of that, Rebecca?

GRANT: It's possible. I wouldn't mind seeing a meeting in Beijing. But we're waiting to find out. The border remains a really logical location.

Let's not forget Kim does have an airplane. It's an old Aleutian airliner that he purchased from the Soviet Union back in the day, so he can go where he needs to go. But I think the real issue here, it was probably a fairly tense meeting.

China's been very unhappy with North Korea. Kim has created no end of trouble for them. So I think there were probably some stern words exchanged, whoever was in that meeting. And China will have reminded North Korea what they said last August, and that is, if you start trouble, you are on your own.

That was one of the key breakthroughs that led over time to this place where we're now about to have an important summit and we have a chance to pull this back from the brink. I'm glad to see China doing this. They are communist countries. They like to keep it quiet. But I see this meeting, whoever was in it, as definitely a positive step forward.

CAVUTO: Now I'm going to be sound like I'm reading a Bob Ludlum novel, Marc, but is this an effort on the Chinese part to say, we are so over you, Kim Jong-un? You have been such an embarrassment. You're going away. You're taking a little trip.

LOTTER: I don't know if it's going to go that far, but it is good to see that they're continuing to work with the maximum pressure campaign.

And I do think, to Rebecca's point, when they said that, if you make trouble, you're on your own, that's a significant step. Also, let's not underscore at the same time that the U.S. today, yesterday announced that we have got a framework in place for the new economic agreement with South Korea.

So, again, North Korea feels the noose tightening around it, whether it's from China, whether they have got new economic cooperation with the United States to the south. These are all things that are coming together to make sure that we deal with the North Korean threat, and deal with it quickly.

CAVUTO: All right. Guys, thank you both very, very much.

Again, we have no real details yet on what's going on in Beijing, who's there, what's being discussed, who is strong-arming who, if any of that is going on.

What we do know is the odd confluence of events where you have sanctions that have pressured the North Koreans and now tariffs that have pressured the Chinese that might, might, might be producing results. We will simply have to see.

All right, if you ever see these census surveys, they ask you a lot of general questions, like how many rooms in your house, how many cars you have. But are you an American citizen? We used to ask that all the time. Suddenly, it's become sacrilege. And suddenly, because we are, California is suing -- after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: You know, you think about it, the whole census is about counting every now and then how many Americans live in this country. But, apparently, it's grown to a great offense if you're ever that general or vague.

For example, the Trump administration adding the line about your citizenship. Are you a U.S. citizen? Well, that was enough to get California to sue, saying it's a big leap, even though it used to be a common and pretty frequently asked question.

Kevin Corke at the White House on how they're responding to this -- Kevin.

KEVIN CORKE, FOX NEWS WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Hey there, Neil.

You're right about that. Listen, this is the 2020 census we're talking about. And as you mentioned, this is fairly common stuff, with the exception of the 2010 census asking about your citizenship status.

Well, I should point out as well, California's A.G. is opposed asking that question. Xavier Becerra is calling it a deliberate effort to scare Californians.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

XAVIER BECERRA (D), CALIFORNIA ATTORNEY GENERAL: Given the way that this administration has attacked immigrants, you can understand why immigrant families would be afraid to fill out the census questionnaire.

The Trump administration has yet again failed to learn from history. They fail to consider the consequences of scaring people into not filling out the census forms.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CORKE: But, as you can well imagine, White House officials say, listen, this is the Commerce Department's call, after all. They may have consulted with them, but they do have the final call. They also add fairly quickly that this is not unprecedented in any way.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH HUCKABEE SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: Look, this is a question that's been included in every census since 1965, with the exception of 2010, when it was removed. We have contained this question that's provided data that's necessary for the Department of Justice to protect voters and specifically to help us better comply.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CORKE: Well, I just want to remind you this is not the first time, Neil, we have actually seen the A.G. and the state of California sue the Trump administration.

Mr. Becerra also suing over the proposed border wall enhancement down in San Diego and along the U.S.-Mexico border. By the way, for the folks that don't understand the real importance here, it's not just about counting people. We're talking about political representation and federal funding.

So you can well imagine, Neil, why the state of California wants to make sure that they're getting everyone counted, even if some of them may not be here legally -- Neil.

CAVUTO: Yes, all right, thank you very, very much, Kevin Corke.

Bottom line here, this always morphs into a discussion -- I'm a stickler for using the right words for things when I can and when they apply -- but to say that this morphed into being scaring immigrants, well, if it would scare anyone, I guess it would be illegal immigrants.

There is a big difference. We're a nation of immigrants, so are we scaring everybody, everyone who answers this survey?

It's a question my next guest is asking as well, FOX News contributor Kevin Jackson.

Kevin, I mean, the idea that if you're here illegally that this somehow is targeting you, when in fact this all started with counting the number of legal Americans here, and then criticizing and suing over the fear that this will affect all immigrants, that's -- that's a stretch. But your thoughts.

KEVIN JACKSON, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Yes, of course it is.

You know, Californians are living on another planet. Look, this is a very simple thing, Neil. And everybody watching your program, the millions watching FOX News know this. This is California's attempt to minimize the vote of legal citizens.

And it has nothing to do with immigrants. And in fact I love that the Trump administration invoked the 1965 Civil -- or Voting Rights Act, rather, in bringing this back, because, effectively, Barack Obama ignored that and violated that Civil Rights Act.

This is something that is supposed to protect citizens in keeping the vote from being watered down. The other thing is California's been losing citizens quite readily because of the craziness of Jerry Brown and the tactics of these legislators out there who are doing things like allowing people with AIDS to infect people.

They're passing laws and legislation that do not protect their citizens. So this is -- but Sarah -- stretching something, trying to make it racist, when in fact when they undid it in 2010, that really should have been considered racist, and certainly not protecting U.S. citizens.

CAVUTO: But, you know, I do notice a greater concern with not offending those who are here illegally. Fine. If that's your wont, fine.

I know it's become a sanctuary state. I know the mayor of Oakland won't even allow ICE to come in without giving local residents, those who are here illegally, a heads-up. But now to start saying that a census that was meant to keep count of the number of legal American citizens in any given community and state to determine and apportion out the number of benefits they should receive and what they should be getting from the United States government down the road has become a much greater fixation on those who -- who aren't here legally, who shouldn't be here legally, who they take great offense to protecting by morphing them into all immigrants.

(CROSSTALK)

JACKSON: Look, Neil, this is one of these topics where I guarantee you people are watching this program right now saying to themselves, where has common sense gone in this country, when we know for a fact that the census is there to do one thing?

It is to apportion votes, period, to apportion legislators. What is California trying to do when they say, we want to count the illegals? I don't care about the sanctuary states and all that. We want to count illegals as part of our population, and we don't want you to question whether somebody's here legally or illegally.

That's only got one outcome. And that's because California is losing companies. It's losing citizens, people who are tired of being taxed into oblivion, people who can be put in jail because they use the wrong pronoun or they don't believe in climate -- global climate farce. There are people leaving in drones.

And instead of addressing the real issue, they want to cover it up by saying, let's count everybody that's here. That's ridiculous.

And people in America are sick of this. And, quite frankly, these counties, Los Alamitos and people like this, that are saying, we're not going to participant in this nonsense of Jerry Brown, are starting to speak out.

CAVUTO: Yes, it's just getting crazy. It deemed bigoted or racist if you're just trying to get to the bottom of something...

(LAUGHTER)

CAVUTO: ... or to allow this to morph in, just when we had the illegal immigrant debate.

And then they just dropped off illegal, and said, well, anti-immigrant. And then, once again, in the wording of this lawsuit, that's exactly how it came across. But it is a weird world.

All right, thank you very, very much, my friend.

We have a lot more coming up here.

But you know by now that Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook fame is ready to testify before Congress. Here's the thing about the guy. He is a genius. He is a genius. No one can deny that. You don't create a multibillion- dollar behemoth if you're an idiot.

But not great taking questions. Not great sometimes on camera. You know, we can't be gifted teleprompter readers, my friend. I'm telling you, though, that could be a big issue for him and for an entire industry. I'm telling you. He's got more pressure on him than me at a fruit stand.

I will explain.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: All right. Facebook's in a bear market. It is down north of 20 percent. What that means for you and for Mark Zuckerberg when he comes to Congress to testify. He will be poorer and under pressure.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: All right. Smile for the cameras, Mark. Looks like Zuck won't duck Congress after all. Reports the Facebook CEO, Mark Zuckerberg, will indeed testify before Congress on this data scandal.

There could be others as well. Seems that everyone wants a piece of him, talk to him, and get an idea on how it is the privacy of better than 50 million of his users was compromised.

Market watcher Burt Flickinger and attorney Emily Compagno on this.

Burt, you know, if you think about it, the enormous pressure on him now, not just for his company, but for an industry that very much fears a federal fix, is that in the offing here, depending on how he does?

BURT FLICKINGER, STRATEGIC RESOURCE GROUP: It is in the offing, Neil.

And, as you referenced with the fruit stand, Zuckerberg is under unprecedented pressure, because the government and the citizens need to know, after reports of Facebook, Google fixing the news, where there's up to 23 percent of the news flow before presidential elections, and this most recent concerning set of circumstances.

And in terms of not testifying in before the British Parliament, that's absolutely outrageous. Winston Churchill did that in a matter of hours. And before Congress, Casey Stengel, Mickey Mantle, and Roger Maris -- you can look it up -- testified in '58, the same way Howard Hughes did in 1974.

And the whole market could be under pressure with Mark Zuckerberg, because it's a matter of trust. And without trust, you don't have consumer confidence and, ultimately, Facebook doesn't have a product, this great social media strategist, Mary Jane Mellet of SocialClique, reference.

And Zuckerberg isn't doing social media at Harvard College, to Elliott House, and elsewhere. He's got tremendous accountability and responsibility. And as, Ms. Mellet says, he has to change his behavior, or Facebook will lose its relevance and could crater the markets.

CAVUTO: Well, therein lies -- you know, and I will talk to the attorney here, Emily Compagno.

The fact of the matter is, he's, you know, a very, very smart tech guy. He built this from nothing. It started as a dating service. And it's obviously something much bigger now. But, Emily, he is going to be ripped apart. And he has got to answer the proverbial question that these things always come down the, what did you know, when did you know it, how did you botch it, were you covering it up?

And they will be relentless, because they will, politicians probably of both sides, be trying to finger him and saying, this is something we have got to fix, much like they tried to fix banks, much like they tried big tobacco. And they're going to lump him in with that. So, what does he do?

EMILY COMPAGNO, ATTORNEY: Well, regardless -- look, here's the deal.

Whether they want to fix it or not, the important issue here is transparency. We all know the FTC is investigating Facebook right now, in part because of their likely violation of the 2011 settlement where they agreed to get express consent by every user before sharing their privacy -- sharing their data outside the bounds of their privacy agreement.

Now, that is a non-public investigation. So, what that means is, the public will have no visibility into that investigation whatsoever. And he has been and Facebook has been invited by multiple committees on the congressional Hill, right?

So, it's about as well how the government wants to define or how our government wants to kind of categorize Facebook. Do we define it as a media group, as a newspaper?

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: But tech guys are not savvy at this. They're brilliant, a lot of I.Q., not a lot of E.Q. And that could run against him.

I'm not trying to disparage him. I'm just trying to say, that's the -- you know, the bane of existence for geniuses, right?

COMPAGNO: Right.

But I think the larger question is that they, they meaning Facebook and Zuckerberg, was responsible for almost two billion users' private data, of which 50 million was breached. And so I think here the larger question is whether it's in our best interest, our meaning the consumers, to regulate that environment, or at least to get some answers, to find out what he knew and when, as you said, and moving forward how that can be better regulated to protect the consumer.

CAVUTO: Right.

COMPAGNO: So, it's not whether his E.Q. or I.Q. will kind of damage his own credibility. It's whether we will get the answers that the public deserves. And Congress right now, depending on how we categorize it, it's important for us moving forward to know how to operate within that regulatory framework.

And that's something that will play out.

CAVUTO: Yes, but we're not going to get those answers. We're not going to get those answers, Burt.

He's going to be limited by his own lawyers about what he can say, especially with an FTC investigation going on concurrently.

FLICKINGER: Emily is completely correct. And as the great U.S. spokesperson and comedian Lucille Ball of Jamestown, New York, said, Zuckerberg's got a lot of 'splaining to do.

(LAUGHTER)

FLICKINGER: And with that, so far, his response -- Howard Hughes had a tough time socially in testifying, but he helped himself with testifying.

So far, Zuckerberg and Facebook have folded faster than this number one ranked Harvard hockey preseason team that didn't even make the playoffs.

They have done a lot of damage. And they could really damage the Nasdaq and the market with their obtuseness and being so opaque.

CAVUTO: All right.

FLICKINGER: And as Emily said so well, transparency is key to protect the consumer, which is critical.

CAVUTO: All right, well put.

We will see, because the pressure builds next month, when all this goes down.

All right, guys, thank you, very, very much.

Well, for those who thought that the administration would be pussyfooting around with dealing with the Russians, proof that it is not. All those Russian diplomats who were kicked out and, suddenly, suddenly, the Democratic critics who are so silent.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: What's Russian for, oh, no, you didn't-ski?

(LAUGHTER)

CAVUTO: I don't know.

I do know that Rich Edson is at the State Department, where they're trying to brace for what the Russia response will be, our kicking out 60 of their diplomats -- Rich.

RICH EDSON, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good afternoon, Neil.

And other countries are now joining. More Russians are heading home, as NATO, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, and Australia announced that they are also joining more than two dozen countries in kicking out more than 150 Russian diplomats.

The Russian government is vowing to retaliate. The foreign minister, Sergei Lavrov, says -- quote -- "Rest assured, we will respond. The reason is that no one would like to tolerate such obnoxiousness, and we won't either."

He says the United States used colossal pressure and blackmail to push other countries to join it in kicking out these diplomats.

And the State Department says it still has not heard from Russia since it made the initial announcement. The expectation here is that the response of the Russians will mirror what the United States did, which is kick out 60 diplomats, close the consulate in Seattle.

This deteriorating relationship between the United States and Russia, that will fall to the next secretary of state. That's expected to be the CIA director, Mike Pompeo, who is actually here right now. Arrived around 2:00 this afternoon. Officials say he's meeting with top State Department staff here. He's also working on his confirmation hearing, preparing for that. That is expected next month.

And he will be the next secretary of state if the Senate confirms him. Now, the State Department has been saying throughout the day, as has the White House, that they're willing to have a better relationship with Russia. But the problem is, they need to see change in Russian behavior. And thus far, they have seen none of that -- Neil.

CAVUTO: All right, thank you, my friend.

In the meantime, all the criticism that a lot of Democrats had particularly of this president, that he was very soft on Russia, very, very unwilling to take on Russia, now, of course, has agitated Russia over so many of its diplomats getting kicked out courtesy one president Donald J. Trump.

To retired General Jerry Boykin.

General, what do you make of this?

LT. GEN. JERRY BOYKIN (RET.), U.S. ARMY: Yes.

Well, first of all, keep in mind that all countries have people that are doing human intelligence inside their embassies. And most of them have diplomatic cover. So the fact that we are sending 60 of the Russians home doesn't mean that the human intelligence collection effort will not continue here.

But I will tell you, this 26, 27 countries, they have come together because of the leadership of Donald Trump. And that was one of the objectives, is to form this coalition to send a very strong message to the Russians.

CAVUTO: Now, the president let his staff, you know, go ahead and do this, send a signal clear, let it be handled through the State Department, go through all the protocols that you would expect something like this would be done.

But I haven't heard from those who criticized him, assuming that he owes Vladimir Putin something or that he wouldn't take on Vladimir Putin. You would expect that there would be an acknowledgement here, whether you like President Trump or not, that on this particular issue at this particular time he did the right thing.

BOYKIN: Well, you know, it's more of the same. They're not going to give him credit for doing anything.

I mean, what have they given him credit for? They have been continually critical of him, in spite of his successes in his first year-plus.

But, look, I think this is a very significant issue here, because think about this. You have 26, 27 countries that are all telling Russia, you are not going to get away with these shenanigans in our countries and we're going to punish you.

And that is an embarrassment for Vladimir Putin personally, but it is also difficult for them to carry on and continue the way they have been operating, particularly in these countries. And I think this coalition will grow before it's all over with.

CAVUTO: General, while I have got you, I would be curious to get your thoughts on Kim Jong-un of North Korea apparently in China. There's obviously a great deal of pressure there. The Chinese are feeling the tariffs squeeze, the North Koreans the sanctions squeeze. Are the two related?

BOYKIN: Well, yes, I think they are related, unquestionably.

The Chinese know that the North Koreans are feeling the squeeze. They know that there's internal unrest in North Korea, which could result in all kinds of bad things happening there. But I think that the Chinese are very concerned also that Kim is going into a meeting with Donald Trump, and he is not prepared for that meeting.

And I think they're trying to prevent him from giving away the farm. Now, I think that that's that's -- they are wrong in thinking that that might happen, because I don't think Kim has actually made a decision he's going to give up his nuclear weapons yet.

But China has -- I think has a real concern about where this is all going, with him meeting with and negotiating with Donald Trump.

CAVUTO: Do you think they will keep him there, that he's not going back to North Korea?

BOYKIN: No, I think he's going back to North Korea. I don't think that that's going to happen.

But I got to tell you, the best solution to this whole thing, Neil, in my view, is that the Chinese take him out. Just wipe this guy out. I don't think that's going to happen anytime soon, though.

But it's a perplexing situation for the Chinese, just like it is for the Americans and the South Koreans. But, ultimately, I think Donald Trump is going to prevail in this, because he's shown such strong leadership against a guy that has never really had anybody stand up to him like this.

And these sanctions are hurting him and hurting the North Korean people. And that is a -- that is a recipe for disaster, if he doesn't do something very quickly.

CAVUTO: Yes. It is weird stuff. It might be a one-way train ticket, to your point. We shall see.

General, thank you so much.

BOYKIN: Thank you, Neil.

CAVUTO: All right, we told you about California, essentially a sanctuary stat when it comes to illegals and all that stuff, suing anyone who dares threaten the protection for those who aren't necessarily citizens.

But not everyone wants to be a sanctuary state. Some are trying to seek sanctuary from the sanctuary thing, including one community where a vote is any minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: Do you think California is hurting itself, hurting its reputation by doing this, the mayor of Oakland, the governor who support these type of measures?

MICHELLE STEEL, ORANGE COUNTY SUPERVISOR: Oh, my God, yes.

Mayor of Oakland tells everybody that this is racist. That has nothing to do with it. We don't want any criminals walking on the street.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: All right, that is simply how the Orange County supervisor, Michelle Steel, saw it.

Orange County wants a sanctuary from this sanctuary movement. She and other county officials are about to put their revolt to a vote.

Trace Gallagher in Los Angeles with the latest on how that's expected to go -- Trace.

TRACE GALLAGHER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: You know, Neil, this effort in Orange County began as a symbolic gesture, a way for the county to stand behind the city of Los Alamitos, which opted out of California's sanctuary law a couple of weeks ago.

But breaking right now, Orange County supervisors, who, by the way, are all Republicans, have just voted to condemn California's sanctuary law. On top of that, they want to join the federal lawsuit against California.

And they're still debating, but it's also possible the county could file its own lawsuit against the state. Remember, under sanctuary laws, local police are not allowed to notify federal immigration agents when they have illegal immigrants in custody. In other words, instead of deporting criminal aliens, they're set free.

For example, from January 1 to March 19, Orange County released 172 illegal immigrant inmates back into the communities. They'd been arrested for domestic violence, driving under the influence and criminal threats.

Unclear how many have re-offended. But now Orange County Sheriff Sandra Hutchens, who was using a who's in jail online database to notify the public about exactly when inmates, including illegal inmates, are being set free, so now the information is all out there.

And that should allow ICE agents to be in the right place at the right time to pick these people up, Neil. But, yes, the vote is in. Orange County condemned sanctuary city policies, joining the federal lawsuit.

CAVUTO: You know what I don't understand, Trace, is -- that's one issue in Orange County, then, but quite another, let's say you wander into Oakland, right?

GALLAGHER: Sure.

I mean, and Oakland is on the other side of this spectrum, right? Oakland Mayor Libby Schaaf has many times said, look, we -- she still stands behind this. Even with all the criticism, even with some people in the Democratic Party criticizing her, she stands behind that decision to notify ICE -- or notify illegal immigrants that ICE agents were coming down on them -- Neil.

CAVUTO: All right, thank you very much, Trace Gallagher in California.

GALLAGHER: Sure.

CAVUTO: All right, Orange Undersheriff Don Barnes, by the way, will be my special guest tomorrow on this show, this push right now that has a state divided, and the middle of this state now suing, suing the federal government, more to the point, the Trump administration and the Commerce Department, over a simple question that is included in this year's census: Are you a legal citizen of this country?

More after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: Everything goes back to Facebook. The stock that is now in bear market territory, having fallen 21 percent from its high, has now buffeted the entire sector.

Today was maybe just a flash, but I'm telling here, the fear seems to be that the government is sniffing around. That can't be good. It won't only sniff around Facebook. It wants to talk to a lot of other players here.

And that has Wall Street thinking, oh, no. Been there, done that, don't want to see it again.

We will see you tomorrow.

"The Five" is now.

END

urn:contentItem:5RYX-5BF1-DXH2-635V-00000-00Facebook CEO to Appear Before Congress; Census Controversy; Kim Jong-un Visiting China?; Dow Drops; California's Sanctuary City Fight2018-03-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:45:28ZLexisNexisYOUR WORLD WITH NEIL CAVUTO4:00 PM ESTJerry Boykin, Burt Flickinger, Emily Compagno, Marc Lotter, Rebecca Grant, John Tamny, Bob Iaccino, Jonas Max FerrisNEWSInternational032701cb.140Facebook CEO to Appear Before Congress; Census Controversy; Kim Jong-un Visiting China?; Dow Drops; California's Sanctuary City FightTrace Gallagher, Rich Edson, Kevin Jackson, Kevin Corke, Ashley Webster, Neil Cavuto

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

NEIL CAVUTO, HOST: In your Facebook.

Are investors freaking out because the government could be digging in and way beyond Facebook?

Welcome, everybody. I'm Neil Cavuto.

New fears right now that Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg might not be alone, that there are other tech companies that are getting caught up in the, hey, we're from the United States government and we would like to chat.

Nvidia plunging today after suspending self-driving tests. That's got local government interest. Tesla dropping to its lowest level in almost a year amid reports that the government is investigating a Tesla vehicle crash in California and wants to know what exactly happened.

Then there's the case of Microsoft, which was supposed to be the next trillion-dollar company. Reports now it was among the most poorly performing Dow stocks, and no one, no one is investigating Microsoft.

What is going on here with this widening concern in Washington that, you know, we'd like to get a handle on this? The problem with Washington wanting to get a handle on something is, well, sellers get a handle on selling and selling and selling. And by day's end, down about 334.5 points.

The Russian government is vowing to retaliate. The foreign minister, Sergei Lavrov, says -- quote -- "Rest assured, we will respond. The reason is that no one would like to tolerate such obnoxiousness, and we won't either."

He says the United States used colossal pressure and blackmail to push other countries to join it in kicking out these diplomats.

And the State Department says it still has not heard from Russia since it made the initial announcement. The expectation here is that the response of the Russians will mirror what the United States did, which is kick out 60 diplomats, close the consulate in Seattle.

This deteriorating relationship between the United States and Russia, that will fall to the next secretary of state. That's expected to be the CIA director, Mike Pompeo, who is actually here right now. Arrived around 2:00 this afternoon. Officials say he's meeting with top State Department staff here. He's also working on his confirmation hearing, preparing for that. That is expected next month.

And he will be the next secretary of state if the Senate confirms him. Now, the State Department has been saying throughout the day, as has the White House, that they're willing to have a better relationship with Russia. But the problem is, they need to see change in Russian behavior. And thus far, they have seen none of that -- Neil.

CAVUTO: All right, thank you, my friend.

In the meantime, all the criticism that a lot of Democrats had particularly of this president, that he was very soft on Russia, very, very unwilling to take on Russia, now, of course, has agitated Russia over so many of its diplomats getting kicked out courtesy one president Donald J. Trump.

To retired General Jerry Boykin.

General, what do you make of this?

LT. GEN. JERRY BOYKIN (RET.), U.S. ARMY: Yes.

Well, first of all, keep in mind that all countries have people that are doing human intelligence inside their embassies. And most of them have diplomatic cover. So the fact that we are sending 60 of the Russians home doesn't mean that the human intelligence collection effort will not continue here.

But I will tell you, this 26, 27 countries, they have come together because of the leadership of Donald Trump. And that was one of the objectives, is to form this coalition to send a very strong message to the Russians.

CAVUTO: Now, the president let his staff, you know, go ahead and do this, send a signal clear, let it be handled through the State Department, go through all the protocols that you would expect something like this would be done.

But I haven't heard from those who criticized him, assuming that he owes Vladimir Putin something or that he wouldn't take on Vladimir Putin. You would expect that there would be an acknowledgement here, whether you like President Trump or not, that on this particular issue at this particular time he did the right thing.

BOYKIN: Well, you know, it's more of the same. They're not going to give him credit for doing anything.

I mean, what have they given him credit for? They have been continually critical of him, in spite of his successes in his first year-plus.

But, look, I think this is a very significant issue here, because think about this. You have 26, 27 countries that are all telling Russia, you are not going to get away with these shenanigans in our countries and we're going to punish you.

And that is an embarrassment for Vladimir Putin personally, but it is also difficult for them to carry on and continue the way they have been operating, particularly in these countries. And I think this coalition will grow before it's all over with.

CAVUTO: General, while I have got you, I would be curious to get your thoughts on Kim Jong-un of North Korea apparently in China. There's obviously a great deal of pressure there. The Chinese are feeling the tariffs squeeze, the North Koreans the sanctions squeeze. Are the two related?

BOYKIN: Well, yes, I think they are related, unquestionably.

The Chinese know that the North Koreans are feeling the squeeze. They know that there's internal unrest in North Korea, which could result in all kinds of bad things happening there. But I think that the Chinese are very concerned also that Kim is going into a meeting with Donald Trump, and he is not prepared for that meeting.

And I think they're trying to prevent him from giving away the farm. Now, I think that that's that's -- they are wrong in thinking that that might happen, because I don't think Kim has actually made a decision he's going to give up his nuclear weapons yet.

But China has -- I think has a real concern about where this is all going, with him meeting with and negotiating with Donald Trump.

CAVUTO: Do you think they will keep him there, that he's not going back to North Korea?

BOYKIN: No, I think he's going back to North Korea. I don't think that that's going to happen.

But I got to tell you, the best solution to this whole thing, Neil, in my view, is that the Chinese take him out. Just wipe this guy out. I don't think that's going to happen anytime soon, though.

But it's a perplexing situation for the Chinese, just like it is for the Americans and the South Koreans. But, ultimately, I think Donald Trump is going to prevail in this, because he's shown such strong leadership against a guy that has never really had anybody stand up to him like this.

And these sanctions are hurting him and hurting the North Korean people. And that is a -- that is a recipe for disaster, if he doesn't do something very quickly.

CAVUTO: Yes. It is weird stuff. It might be a one-way train ticket, to your point. We shall see.

General, thank you so much.

BOYKIN: Thank you, Neil.

CAVUTO: All right, we told you about California, essentially a sanctuary stat when it comes to illegals and all that stuff, suing anyone who dares threaten the protection for those who aren't necessarily citizens.

But not everyone wants to be a sanctuary state. Some are trying to seek sanctuary from the sanctuary thing, including one community where a vote is any minute.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: Do you think California is hurting itself, hurting its reputation by doing this, the mayor of Oakland, the governor who support these type of measures?

MICHELLE STEEL, ORANGE COUNTY SUPERVISOR: Oh, my God, yes.

Mayor of Oakland tells everybody that this is racist. That has nothing to do with it. We don't want any criminals walking on the street.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: All right, that is simply how the Orange County supervisor, Michelle Steel, saw it.

Orange County wants a sanctuary from this sanctuary movement. She and other county officials are about to put their revolt to a vote.

Trace Gallagher in Los Angeles with the latest on how that's expected to go -- Trace.

TRACE GALLAGHER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: You know, Neil, this effort in Orange County began as a symbolic gesture, a way for the county to stand behind the city of Los Alamitos, which opted out of California's sanctuary law a couple of weeks ago.

But breaking right now, Orange County supervisors, who, by the way, are all Republicans, have just voted to condemn California's sanctuary law. On top of that, they want to join the federal lawsuit against California.

And they're still debating, but it's also possible the county could file its own lawsuit against the state. Remember, under sanctuary laws, local police are not allowed to notify federal immigration agents when they have illegal immigrants in custody. In other words, instead of deporting criminal aliens, they're set free.

For example, from January 1 to March 19, Orange County released 172 illegal immigrant inmates back into the communities. They'd been arrested for domestic violence, driving under the influence and criminal threats.

Unclear how many have re-offended. But now Orange County Sheriff Sandra Hutchens, who was using a who's in jail online database to notify the public about exactly when inmates, including illegal inmates, are being set free, so now the information is all out there.

And that should allow ICE agents to be in the right place at the right time to pick these people up, Neil. But, yes, the vote is in. Orange County condemned sanctuary city policies, joining the federal lawsuit.

CAVUTO: You know what I don't understand, Trace, is -- that's one issue in Orange County, then, but quite another, let's say you wander into Oakland, right?

GALLAGHER: Sure.

I mean, and Oakland is on the other side of this spectrum, right? Oakland Mayor Libby Schaaf has many times said, look, we -- she still stands behind this. Even with all the criticism, even with some people in the Democratic Party criticizing her, she stands behind that decision to notify ICE -- or notify illegal immigrants that ICE agents were coming down on them -- Neil.

CAVUTO: All right, thank you very much, Trace Gallagher in California.

GALLAGHER: Sure.

CAVUTO: All right, Orange Undersheriff Don Barnes, by the way, will be my special guest tomorrow on this show, this push right now that has a state divided, and the middle of this state now suing, suing the federal government, more to the point, the Trump administration and the Commerce Department, over a simple question that is included in this year's census: Are you a legal citizen of this country?

More after this.

CAVUTO: Everything goes back to Facebook. The stock that is now in bear market territory, having fallen 21 percent from its high, has now buffeted the entire sector.

Today was maybe just a flash, but I'm telling here, the fear seems to be that the government is sniffing around. That can't be good. It won't only sniff around Facebook. It wants to talk to a lot of other players here.

And that has Wall Street thinking, oh, no. Been there, done that, don't want to see it again.

We will see you tomorrow.

"The Five" is now.

urn:contentItem:5X7M-N0J1-DXVP-V31T-00000-00Facebook CEO to appear before Congress Oct. 232019-10-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:45:28ZLexisNexisBUSINESSFacebook CEO to appear before Congress Oct. 23Marcy Gordon

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg will appear before Congress this month as the tech giant is under pressure from lawmakers and regulators over its massive market power and record of privacy breaches.

Rep. Maxine Waters, D-Los Angeles, who heads the House Financial Services Committee, announced Wednesday that Zuckerberg will testify at a hearing by the panel on Oct. 23. The focus will be on Facebook's plan to create a digital currency and its role in housing. The company agreed in a legal settlement in March to overhaul its ad-targeting systems to prevent discrimination in housing, credit and employment ads.

Lawmakers from both parties and top regulators, including Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, have criticized Facebook's plan for the new currency, expressing concern that it could be used for illicit activity such as money laundering or drug trafficking. There also is concern that the huge reserve created with money used to buy the new currency, to be called Libra, could supplant the Fed and destabilize the financial system, and that consumers could be hurt by Libra losses.

"Mark looks forward to testifying before the House Financial Services Committee and responding to lawmakers' questions," Facebook said Wednesday.

In July, Waters and other committee Democrats sent a letter to Facebook, requesting a halt on moving forward with the currency and with the digital wallet, called Calibra, which would be used in the new currency system. House Democrats also have threatened legislation that would block big tech companies from getting into banking.

Waters has called Libra "a new Swiss-based financial system" that potentially is too big to fail and could require a taxpayer bailout.

France's finance minister said Wednesday that the European Union should not allow Facebook to develop the currency project on "European territory" because it threatens the monetary sovereignty of member countries. "It should not be the role of a private company to try to get a sovereign currency like a sovereign state," Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire said.

Unlike digital currencies such as bitcoin or ether, Facebook's plan calls for Libra to be backed by real currencies.

David Marcus, the Facebook executive leading the project, told lawmakers over two days of congressional hearings in July that Facebook would not start the currency project until it had received all the necessary approvals from regulators and secured safeguards to protect the privacy of users' data. He said Facebook will not control Libra because the Menlo Park company will be only one of about 100 companies and nonprofits in an association that will manage the currency.

The plan would open low-cost online commerce to millions of people around the world who lack access to bank accounts, and would make it cheaper to send money across borders, Marcus said. He did not agree to a suspension of the plan or a pilot project, as several lawmakers urged.

Facebook, a social media giant with nearly 2.5 billion users around the globe, is under heavy scrutiny from lawmakers and regulators after a series of data privacy scandals, including lapses in opening the personal data of millions of users to Donald Trump's 2016 campaign.

The Justice Department, the Federal Trade Commission and the House Judiciary antitrust subcommittee are all conducting investigations of Facebook and other big tech companies amid accusations of abuse of their market power to crush competition.

Zuckerberg had three days of private meetings in Washington last month with Trump and several lawmakers.

Zuckerberg last testified to Congress in the spring, when he was questioned about privacy, election interference and other issues.

Marcy Gordon is an Associated Press writer.

urn:contentItem:5X7J-4FD1-DYN6-W547-00000-00Facebook CEO to appear before Congress on currency plan2019-10-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:45:28ZLexisNexisWASHINGTON DATELINEFacebook CEO to appear before Congress on currency planBy MARCY GORDONAP Business WriterWASHINGTON

WASHINGTON (AP) - Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg will appear before Congress this month as the tech giant is under pressure from lawmakers and regulators over its massive market power and record of privacy breaches.

Rep. Maxine Waters, the California Democrat who heads the House Financial Services Committee, announced Wednesday that Zuckerberg will testify at a hearing by the panel on Oct. 23. The focus will be on Facebook's plan to create a digital currency and its role in housing. The company agreed in a legal settlement in March to overhaul its ad-targeting systems to prevent discrimination in housing, credit and employment ads.

Lawmakers from both parties and top regulators, including Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, have criticized Facebook's plan for the new currency, expressing concern that it could be used for illicit activity such as money laundering or drug trafficking. There also is concern that the massive reserve created with money used to buy the new currency, to be called Libra, could supplant the Fed and destabilize the financial system, and that consumers could be hurt by Libra losses.

"Mark looks forward to testifying before the House Financial Services Committee and responding to lawmakers' questions," Facebook said in a statement Wednesday.

In July, Waters and other committee Democrats sent a letter to Facebook requesting a halt on moving forward with the currency and with the digital wallet, called Calibra, which would be used in the new currency system. House Democrats also have threatened legislation that would block big tech companies from getting into banking.

Waters has called Libra "a new Swiss-based financial system" that potentially is too big to fail and could require a taxpayer bailout.

France's finance minister said Wednesday that the European Union should not allow Facebook to develop the currency project on "European territory" because it threatens the monetary sovereignty of member countries. "It should not be the role of a private company to try to get a sovereign currency like a sovereign state," Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire said.

Unlike digital currencies such as bitcoin or Ethereum, Facebook's plan calls for Libra to be backed by real currencies.

David Marcus, the Facebook executive leading the project, told lawmakers over two days of congressional hearings in July that Facebook would not launch the currency project until it had received all the necessary approvals from regulators and secured safeguards to protect the privacy of users' data. He said Facebook will not control Libra because Facebook will be only one of about 100 companies and nonprofits in an association that will manage the currency.

The plan would open low-cost online commerce to millions of people around the world who lack access to bank accounts, and would make it cheaper to send money across borders, Marcus said. He did not agree to a suspension of the plan or a pilot project, as several lawmakers urged.

Facebook, a social media giant based in Menlo Park, California, with nearly 2.5 billion users around the globe, is under heavy scrutiny from lawmakers and regulators following a series of data privacy scandals, including lapses in opening the personal data of millions of users to President Donald Trump's 2016 campaign.

The Justice Department, the Federal Trade Commission and the House Judiciary antitrust subcommittee are all conducting investigations of Facebook and the other big tech companies amid accusations of abuse of their market power to crush competition.

Zuckerberg had three days of private meetings in Washington last month with Trump and several lawmakers who, like the president, are critics of the tech industry. He also met with the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee to discuss ways to prevent foreign actors from disrupting next year's elections. In a separate session, Zuckerberg told the leaders of the House Judiciary Committee that the company would cooperate with their antitrust investigation.

Zuckerberg last testified to Congress in the spring, when he was questioned about privacy, election interference and other issues.

urn:contentItem:5X7J-4F81-DYN6-W4C4-00000-00Facebook CEO to appear before Congress on currency plan2019-10-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:45:28ZLexisNexisWASHINGTON DATELINEFacebook CEO to appear before Congress on currency planBy MARCY GORDONAP Business WriterWASHINGTON

WASHINGTON (AP) - Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg will appear before Congress this month as the tech giant is under pressure from lawmakers and regulators over its massive market power and record of privacy breaches.

Rep. Maxine Waters, the California Democrat who heads the House Financial Services Committee, announced Wednesday that Zuckerberg will testify at a hearing by the panel on Oct. 23. The focus will be on Facebook's plan to create a digital currency and its role in housing. The company agreed in a legal settlement in March to overhaul its ad-targeting systems to prevent discrimination in housing, credit and employment ads.

Lawmakers from both parties and top regulators, including Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, have criticized Facebook's plan for the new currency, expressing concern that it could be used for illicit activity such as money laundering or drug trafficking. There also is concern that the massive reserve created with money used to buy the new currency, to be called Libra, could supplant the Fed and destabilize the financial system, and that consumers could be hurt by Libra losses.

"Mark looks forward to testifying before the House Financial Services Committee and responding to lawmakers' questions," Facebook said in a statement Wednesday.

In July, Waters and other committee Democrats sent a letter to Facebook requesting a halt on moving forward with the currency and with the digital wallet, called Calibra, which would be used in the new currency system. House Democrats also have threatened legislation that would block big tech companies from getting into banking.

Waters has called Libra "a new Swiss-based financial system" that potentially is too big to fail and could require a taxpayer bailout.

France's finance minister said Wednesday that the European Union should not allow Facebook to develop the currency project on "European territory" because it threatens the monetary sovereignty of member countries. "It should not be the role of a private company to try to get a sovereign currency like a sovereign state," Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire said.

Unlike digital currencies such as bitcoin or Ethereum, Facebook's plan calls for Libra to be backed by real currencies.

David Marcus, the Facebook executive leading the project, told lawmakers over two days of congressional hearings in July that Facebook would not launch the currency project until it had received all the necessary approvals from regulators and secured safeguards to protect the privacy of users' data. He said Facebook will not control Libra because Facebook will be only one of about 100 companies and nonprofits in an association that will manage the currency.

The plan would open low-cost online commerce to millions of people around the world who lack access to bank accounts, and would make it cheaper to send money across borders, Marcus said. He did not agree to a suspension of the plan or a pilot project, as several lawmakers urged.

Facebook, a social media giant based in Menlo Park, California, with nearly 2.5 billion users around the globe, is under heavy scrutiny from lawmakers and regulators following a series of data privacy scandals, including lapses in opening the personal data of millions of users to President Donald Trump's 2016 campaign.

The Justice Department, the Federal Trade Commission and the House Judiciary antitrust subcommittee are all conducting investigations of Facebook and the other big tech companies amid accusations of abuse of their market power to crush competition.

Zuckerberg had three days of private meetings in Washington last month with Trump and several lawmakers who, like the president, are critics of the tech industry. He also met with the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee to discuss ways to prevent foreign actors from disrupting next year's elections. In a separate session, Zuckerberg told the leaders of the House Judiciary Committee that the company would cooperate with their antitrust investigation.

Zuckerberg last testified to Congress in the spring, when he was questioned about privacy, election interference and other issues.

urn:contentItem:5X7J-4FP1-DYN6-W06K-00000-00Facebook CEO to appear before Congress on currency plan2019-10-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:45:28ZLexisNexisBUSINESS NEWSFacebook CEO to appear before Congress on currency planBy MARCY GORDONAP Business WriterWASHINGTON

WASHINGTON (AP) - Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg will appear before Congress this month as the tech giant is under pressure from lawmakers and regulators over its massive market power and record of privacy breaches.

Rep. Maxine Waters, the California Democrat who heads the House Financial Services Committee, announced Wednesday that Zuckerberg will testify at a hearing by the panel on Oct. 23. The focus will be on Facebook's plan to create a digital currency and its role in housing. The company agreed in a legal settlement in March to overhaul its ad-targeting systems to prevent discrimination in housing, credit and employment ads.

Lawmakers from both parties and top regulators, including Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, have criticized Facebook's plan for the new currency, expressing concern that it could be used for illicit activity such as money laundering or drug trafficking. There also is concern that the massive reserve created with money used to buy the new currency, to be called Libra, could supplant the Fed and destabilize the financial system, and that consumers could be hurt by Libra losses.

"Mark looks forward to testifying before the House Financial Services Committee and responding to lawmakers' questions," Facebook said in a statement Wednesday.

In July, Waters and other committee Democrats sent a letter to Facebook requesting a halt on moving forward with the currency and with the digital wallet, called Calibra, which would be used in the new currency system. House Democrats also have threatened legislation that would block big tech companies from getting into banking.

Waters has called Libra "a new Swiss-based financial system" that potentially is too big to fail and could require a taxpayer bailout.

France's finance minister said Wednesday that the European Union should not allow Facebook to develop the currency project on "European territory" because it threatens the monetary sovereignty of member countries. "It should not be the role of a private company to try to get a sovereign currency like a sovereign state," Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire said.

Unlike digital currencies such as bitcoin or Ethereum, Facebook's plan calls for Libra to be backed by real currencies.

David Marcus, the Facebook executive leading the project, told lawmakers over two days of congressional hearings in July that Facebook would not launch the currency project until it had received all the necessary approvals from regulators and secured safeguards to protect the privacy of users' data. He said Facebook will not control Libra because Facebook will be only one of about 100 companies and nonprofits in an association that will manage the currency.

The plan would open low-cost online commerce to millions of people around the world who lack access to bank accounts, and would make it cheaper to send money across borders, Marcus said. He did not agree to a suspension of the plan or a pilot project, as several lawmakers urged.

Facebook, a social media giant based in Menlo Park, California, with nearly 2.5 billion users around the globe, is under heavy scrutiny from lawmakers and regulators following a series of data privacy scandals, including lapses in opening the personal data of millions of users to President Donald Trump's 2016 campaign.

The Justice Department, the Federal Trade Commission and the House Judiciary antitrust subcommittee are all conducting investigations of Facebook and the other big tech companies amid accusations of abuse of their market power to crush competition.

Zuckerberg had three days of private meetings in Washington last month with Trump and several lawmakers who, like the president, are critics of the tech industry. He also met with the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee to discuss ways to prevent foreign actors from disrupting next year's elections. In a separate session, Zuckerberg told the leaders of the House Judiciary Committee that the company would cooperate with their antitrust investigation.

Zuckerberg last testified to Congress in the spring, when he was questioned about privacy, election interference and other issues.

urn:contentItem:5XC7-VNC1-JD3N-53NG-00000-00Facebook CEO urges rivals to buy news2019-10-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:45:28ZLexisNexisWSJPg. 21Facebook CEO urges rivals to buy newsLukas I. Alpert

Facebook chief executive Mark Zuckerberg said the social-mediagiant's decision to pay media outlets who participate in its news service will give a much-needed boost to the publishing industry and provides a model other internet firms should follow.

Multiple major news publishers from the Washington Post to Fox News to The Wall Street Journal have signed on to the service, which launched last Friday with a limited test audience of 200,000 users in the US and will be rolled out more broadly early next year.

Mr Zuckerberg said Facebook's service could have a positive impact on big and small publishers alike, but can't solve the media industry's deep woes on its own.

"I think every internet platform has a responsibility to help fund and support news," he said at an event in New York where he discussed the service with Robert Thomson, chief executive of News Corp, which owns the Journal. "Hopefully others will follow the model we are helping to set up." BuzzFeed editor in chief Ben Smith said Facebook's licensing strategy "is part of a really positive trend that will put a lot of pressure on Google and others to pay publishers".

In a statement, a spokesman for Alphabet's Google said the company played a key role in helping news outlets monetise online content through the traffic its search engine sends to their sites and revenue generated through Google's ad platforms most publishers rely on.

"Every month we send more than 24 billion clicks to publishers' websites," Google said.

"Publishers around the world can use Google tools for monetising their content, and when they do, they receive over 70 per cent of the ad revenue." Facebook has said it plans to include news from as many as 200 publications, although many won't receive licensing fees, the Journal had reported. Among those that are paid, the fees may vary considerably.

In its discussions ahead of the launch, Facebook had offered hundreds of thousands of dollars a year for smaller publishers, a few million for bigger ones, and substantially more for the very largest outlets, according to people familiar with those talks.

The move to pay for news comes as the big tech platforms have come under growing regulatory scrutiny. Google has resisted paying publishers but announced changes to how it ranks stories on its news page to better promote original content, addressing another long-running complaint from publishers.

The new service marked a key shift, said Mr Thomson, who has been sharply critical of Facebook and Google in the past for issues including not paying for news on their platforms.

"Great journalism will only be sustainable at scale if there is a fundamental change in the landscape like this," he said.

Mr Thomson said Facebook's move was "a powerful precedent that will echo around editorial departments".

MEDIA P23

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X35-FVT1-F03R-N2YC-00000-00Facebook CEO visits lawmakers amid push for tech oversight2019-09-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:45:28ZLexisNexisFacebook CEO visits lawmakers amid push for tech oversightMARCY GORDON

Sep 19, 2019( The Today File: https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/ Delivered by Newstex) WASHINGTON (AP) — Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg visited lawmakers Thursday to discuss potential regulation of the tech industry, particularly when it comes to the collection of users' personal data on their platforms.Zuckerberg is discussing oversight of the industry in private meetings with senators including Mark Warner, D-Va., vice chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee; Mike Lee, R-Utah, a senior member of the Senate Judiciary Committee, and Josh Hawley, R-Mo., an outspoken conservative critic of Big Tech.Congress has been debating a privacy law that could sharply rein in the ability of companies like Facebook, Google, Amazon and Apple to collect and make money off users' personal data. A national law, which would be the first of its kind in the U.S., could allow people to see or prohibit use of their data.Acting pre-emptively, Zuckerberg last spring called for tighter regulations to protect consumers' data, control harmful online content, and ensure election integrity and data portability.

The internet 'needs new rules,' he said.Facebook, a social media giant with nearly 2.5 billion users, is under heavy scrutiny from lawmakers and regulators following a series of privacy scandals and amid accusations of abuse of its market power to squash competition.The Justice Department, the Federal Trade Commission and the House Judiciary antitrust subcommittee are all conducting antitrust investigations of the big tech companies, and a bipartisan group of state attorneys general has opened a competition probe specifically of Facebook.AdvertisingIt is Zuckerberg's first public visit to Washington since he testified before Congress last spring about privacy, election interference and other issues.At Facebook's request, Warner helped organize a dinner meeting in Washington Wednesday night for Zuckerberg and a group of senators.'The participants had a discussion touching on multiple issues, including the role and responsibility of social media platforms in protecting our democracy, and what steps Congress should take to defend our elections, protect consumer data, and encourage competition in the social media space,' Rachel Cohen, a spokeswoman for Warner, said in a statement.Warner and Hawley have proposed legislation that would force the tech giants to tell users what data they're collecting from them and how much it's worth. The proposal goes to the heart of Big Tech's hugely profitable business model of commerce in users' personal data. The companies gather vast data on what users read and like, and leverage it to help advertisers target their messages to individuals they want to reach.The tech companies view with particular alarm a separate legislative proposal from Hawley that would require them to prove to regulators that they're not using political bias to filter content. Failing to secure a bias-free audit from the government would mean a social media platform loses its long-held immunity from legal action. MARCY GORDON
